text:
I've never stayed at Paris Las Vegas but I have spent a fair amount of time gaming in there. I love the blue sky and clouds mural on the ceilings and the light effects they do to mimic day light. The casino floor is nice, but I think Paris thinks a bit too highly of themselves because their table minimums were awfully high, and their poker tourneys were set at buy-ins that were so high that they were only filling half of the field.

However, Paris does have one little thing that sets it apart from every other place on the Strip: their breakfast buffet. This breakfast spread they have, set in a Parisian village theme, is absolutely out of control. I have never in my life seen so many different options on a breakfast buffet. At $30\/person, it's steep, but it is an experience you'll never forget. In the "you're not going to believe this just happened to me" Vegas-story fashion, my buddy and I are standing in this incredibly long line waiting to pay our $30 each and these two incredibly cute girls walk out of the buffet area and headed over to us. They asked us if we'd like two free coupons for the buffet; of course we took them graciously and chatted for just a minute. They had to go to the airport and weren't going to be in town to use them. They informed us we didn't have to wait in line, we could just walk in -- and walk in we did. Certain things in life are just perpetual game-changers, and Paris' breakfast buffet is one of them.

Everything you ever wanted or could dream of wanting for breakfast was there. Since that experience, it's been a tradition that every time I'm in town, I go to Paris for breakfast only. They can keep the gaming and sell that to the tourists. If I want to game, I'll go to the MGM, Rio, Caesars or the Bellagio. In fact, Paris could just close its casino as far as I'm concerned and keep the breakfast buffet open. This is also where my nickname "Bullmoose" originated, so it's been a great story to tell!

I am ONLY reviewing the two eating establishments here since we didn't stay here.  It was a time when we were both overly hungry and needed food ASAP.  The sandwich from the hotel was great the first bite and it got exponentially worse after every bite, since I was no longer starving.  Then we headed to that madeline's bakery that had just opened and ordered some eclairs.  Those eclairs looked good but the dough was gummy and soggy.  The cream tasted like Jello instant vanilla pudding and the chocolate outside tasted like Jello chocolate pudding.  All in all, everything looked pretty but didn't taste great.

Me and my husband got married at this hotel last month. I stayed in a standard room with my family for the first two nights, and the room was just alright. Nothing fancy or impressive about it. For our wedding night, we booked a suite and requested early check-in. When I attempted to check in that morning, the lady told me that a suite wasn't available yet and to try again later. Totally understandable since I knew that early check-in wasn't guaranteed. The thing that got me though was when I asked her to please call me when a suite became available. She replied, "This is a big hotel. We don't do that." WOW. I'm sorry that I'm not worth a simple phonecall, especially when I am getting married in your hotel and paying nearly $20,000 for the chapel and catering services!  Minus three stars for the rude customer service at the front desk!

Paris Hotel is famous for its iconic Eiffel towel.  Just across the famous Bellagio Water Fountain. Their parking garage is short walking distance similar to Montel Carlo, however be aware is been shared by Bally as well.  You had to walk by army of slow machines and tablets before you can get to the lobby or elevator.  For guess will be okay but if you are a self-parking hotel will not like that idea at all, the check-in lobby had many beautiful Chandeliers.  

One thing irony, they had dancer near the gaming tablet.  I just do not see any French Connection with that.  However, does had entertainment value and definite can cause distraction to those who play that. 

I was not that fan of their interior style, a fan like it but it does not see too impressive or most romantic.  The crowd was mostly in older 40 and higher.  I do wanted to go up the Eiffel towel in the near future.

This is close to a 2 star review.  I stayed 3 nights at Paris in late September\/early October of 2016.  We arrived well before check in time (which is 4 pm).  My room was ready, which was great, but I was told there would be a $25 or so fee for early check in.  I didn't want to deal with the bell desk holding my luggage, so I just paid it.  But, it's frustrating when the room is sitting there cleaned and ready to go and they still charge you.  I get that Caesars is a corporation and needs to make money, but I feel like more and more places in Vegas (not limited to Caesars properties, see the parking charges at MGM joints now) are nickel and diming you at every opportunity.  Very annoying.

The room is below average for comparably priced hotels on the Strip.  The center of the room has a sort of wardrobe cabinet with 2 areas for hanging clothes on either side and a small fridge in the middle.  The room safe is in there as well.  It was serviceable and got the job done, but it had clearly seen better days.  Many scuffs, scratches, dings, etc.  2 of the magnetic doors didn't work, so you had to kind of rest of the door instead of actually getting it closed.  And, it is located in the center, which means they put the TV on the wall off to the side.  Not a great location and difficult to see from certain areas of the room.

The bathroom had a lot of counter space, which was nice.  There is a small square shower and a soaking tub.  It's similar to the basic bathroom at Bellagio, but not nearly as nice, smaller, and clearly more worn.  While we were staying at Paris they were doing quite a bit of construction (which was loud at times).  I don't know if they are renovating all of the rooms, but the renovation is a good idea.  Given other options on the strip, an upgrade to the accommodations is sorely needed at Paris.

The casino is decent size with several areas for table games, including the massive forest of slots and video poker machines that populate all casino floors.  The sportsbook is on the smaller side, but we were able to get a table to ourselves to watch college football on Saturday.  At a lot of the larger books this is difficult during football season.  But, we only had a cocktail waitress for the first half, during the second half of our game we had to go to the bar to get drinks.

There are some solid restaurants at Paris, including Gordon Ramsay Steak and Mon Ami Gabi.  Additionally, you've got several quick places to get a bite, including JJ's Boulangerie and the Creperie.  The line for crepes can get long depending on the time of day.  I haven't eaten at the Paris buffet in years, but when I went I recall it being better than average.  Also, during my stay, I never saw lines that were close to the massive lines you'll see at the more popular buffets (like Bellagio or Caesars).  

I would stay at Paris again if i were offered a good deal for the room, and if I had a newly upgraded room.  For the price you pay at Paris, you can get a much nicer room at other locations on the Strip.  But, if they renovate well, I'd come back.

Refuse resort fees from Caesar's properties until the included services are improved! While this review is largely a gripe about the Mandara Spa at Paris, I'm making it a review of the Casino\/hotel because of the utter scam of their resort fees. I stayed in a newly renovated Burgundy Room. It is fresher, but lacking any kind of notable luxury. If you're paying for the room, they are not worth paying extra. I've stayed at both Paris and Planet Hollywood a number of times, loved these properties and was usually comped rooms. Now, even if you are comped, you must pay a resort fee of $30+ a day. They attach value to it by telling you that all guests can use the spa facilities, and that free wi-fi is included. The Wi-fi is functional, but slow. My phone data is faster. If it wasn't included, I actually wouldn't have any real reason to use it... my phone and tablet both have data plans, and I like to spend my time at a casino gambling, eating, drinking, and sleeping. It has almost no value for me. 

Likewise, if you don't pay the resort fees (and the only folk that don't are, I believe Seven Stars members), a trip to the Spa facilities is about $25\/day. This is a fee that I've gladly paid in the past to slip in a couple times a day and use the jacuzzi, steam room, and sauna, then perhaps sit and read in a chaise to relax, while enjoying some juice and water to rehydrate after the rigors of casino fun.

However, now those services are "included" (a clever way for you not to be able to ask for a refund of the spa fee, a thing you would certainly do, if you pay it a visit). The Spa facilities at Paris are very very tired. Beyond that, they are barely functional. I'm pretty good at overlooking small annoyances, but my trip to the spa today was an exercise in futility.

When I arrived, I was issued a locker key. They also used to offer sandals, so that you felt a bit safer walking around the wet ground that was probably crawling with micro-organisms. I changed into the robe in the locker, used the toilet (that was the only functional thing in the spa, by the way, but I have one in my room too), and prepared to shower. 

- The shower room was dim, and noticeably infested with gnats or small flies. They were probably just after the water, but their presence speaks to poor cleaning in the shower rooms. 
- The shower area was bereft of towels. I had to acquire one from the front locker area (but even then, the towels were not well-stocked).
- After showering, I turned the timer for the jacuzzi and nothing happened. I waddled out to the men's locker room reception area, and waited for the attendant to appear (there is no bell to summon them, and they're understaffed).
- He informed me that the Jacuzzi was fine, but the jets weren't working (a previous guest had hit the emergency stop button, and it needed to be reset by professionals). He said the water was hot, just not moving.
- I went back to the jacuzzi, stepped into the water, and it was only slightly warmer than room temperature, so didn't feel that there was any reason to soak. Plus, tepid water combined with no jets means "welcome bacteria." This tub should have been off-limits, and the debris in the bottom was alarming.
- I shrugged it off and decided to try the steam and sauna. The steam room was okay, but smelled off, like the mechanisms hadn't been cleaned properly. I stayed for a few minutes, but decided to try one last thing...
- The dry sauna. The temp there was no warmer than the less-than-tepid jacuzzi water. Surely not more than 80 degrees F. There didn't seem to be an accessible dial where it could be turned up.
- I gave up. I was dripping from the steam room, so returned to the shower to clean up, where there were still no towels. So, back to the front, get a new towel, shower with the flies, and dry off. 

Every place has bad days, but reviews of the spa are bad for a reason. This doesn't appear to be a lone case. I recently stayed at the Harrah's in Reno, NV, and had an almost identical experience at their spa facilities (also "included" in the resort fees). Nothing worked, everything was dingy and smelled like infection.

The problem with including services in mandatory resort fees is that you can't really ask for a refund or just avoid the services, and if you never use them, you don't realize that they aren't worth paying for, which gives Caesar's Entertainment NO REASON to fix anything. 

My tip to the stalwart: tell them you will not pay the resort fees until the services are worth the price. They very clearly state what the fees are for; if you don't need Wi-fi and don't want to spend time in a broken down spa, these fees do nothing. Refuse them.

There's not enough space for me to review the tedious "Express Check-in" or the under-staffed registration desk. Make this right, Caesar's! I used to love you, but get more value from Cosmopolitan, and I can gamble *anywhere.* - TR member, Platinum, formerly Diamond, probably soon gone.
What I like the most, is the Eiffel tower. It's been 8 years since I've been in France... Just shows how much I'm ready to go back. :)

this review comes from someone who went to gamble and window shop at paris, haven't stayed there, maybe the rooms aren't awful. 
with that being said: i have never felt so instantly claustrophobic and sick when i walked into a room before. the ceiling is painted in this weird faux sky  design and the lighting in there is really low so it makes it look like the most depressing, awful weather  ever. the air is dank and the ventilation is pathetic. i get that vegas is overwhelming and as inauthentic as you can get, but this was truly sickening. skip it.

I always enjoy my time at Paris. I've only stayed here once but I always stop by whenever I'm Vegas for some reason or another. They have some of the tastiest restaurants with Mon Ami Gabi being a personal favorite. The rooms are well accommodated but a little outdated, especially compared to some of the newer kids on the block like the Cosmo. There are lots of little shops, tons of slot machines and a lot to do overall. The location is great - center strip.

We stayed at Paris for one night and we will revisit the hotel again but not stay overnight. The hotel itself was beautiful. The decor was perfect for a Paris theme and the restaurants were great. They had really great breakfast. The room itself was a major disappointment. Their beds were not comfortable and the bathroom was rusted and looked like it had mildew.

Stayed at this hotel our last night in Vegas as it is my love's birthday. We were upgraded to a suite on the 29th floor over looking the Eiffel Tower, the pools and the water show at the Bellagio. The room itself was lovely. We had a dining area, a living room with plasma TV, 2 bathrooms(one with a shower and one with a large jacuzzi tub) and a large bedroom w\/plasma TV. We were totally enthralled with our room and our view, but sadly, I cannot give it 5 stars for the following reasons:

-the bedding was old and getting threadbare-it kind of itched a bit at first.
-the towels were also old. Not what I would expect for a suite that can go for over 3K per night.
-no robes provided
-light switches were strangely located and the lamp set-up near the bed was less than stellar.

We ordered room service for breakfast and while some things were wonderful(they brought the requested candle in the grapefruit), most of the food was generic and not nearly as good as the breakfasts we had at the Renaissance. 

I would stay here again, especially in a suite overlooking everything again.

We are local Las Vegas residents.  We wanted to treat our kids to a staycation with a nice night away.  We also wanted to support our community following the mass shooting.  The financial impact from the shooting has hit the strip hard and as 20 year Las Vegas locals, we thought bringing our business there was a good way to help.

We arrived and checked in.  The room was beautiful with a great view of the pool and neighboring hotels.  We ate dinner on property (Mon Ami Gabi--delicious!) and walked the strip a bit before heading to our room.  We all fell asleep around 10 but were awakened shortly thereafter by loud thumping music and someone on a loud speaker.  It turns out our room was directly under the rooftop nightclub.  For the next hour we all tried to sleep but the shaking and pounding and yelling was far too much to handle, even for a heavy sleeper like me.  We finally called the front desk around 11 and requested a new room but we were told the entire resort was sold out.  We were offered ear plugs!  We declined and begged to speak to a manager, but they refused.  Around midnight we had experienced enough.  We packed our bags, headed down to registration, checked out, and headed home.  The staff was indifferent and unconcerned.  They seemed to be reading from an old, tired script.  Clearly they have heard the same complaints for years.   

We were lucky, we live nearby and could easily go home.  I feel awful for those poor, unsuspecting visitors who travel far from home to experience a trip like ours only to be let down by an awful situation that the resort has no interest in remedying.  I suggest anyone coming to Vegas look elsewhere.  There are plenty of beautiful hotels priced within the same range that offer better customer service and don't stick unsuspecting guests directly below an all night rooftop club.

Ok so First off the parking garage is a mess! I was lost and confused on how the get to the next level while trying to find parking. Then I couldn't find the darn hotel elevator! I walked around the entire casino! 
Found them and went to the room and immediately changed and went to the pool. It was ok. At least the pool was "heated" 
That tub in the room was very unattractive for a "Paris" hotel room. Small and ugly. 
I would've rather had a larger shower and no tub. 
The restaurants were a hit or miss! Do not eat at the Beer Park or that Cafe! Awful and a waste of money!!!!!!!!!! Their slot machines are tight and don't pay for nothing. 
I don't recommend staying here.

not much to this place. the only thing good is the location. it's in the middle of the strip. they do have a bomb French bakery in there. that's about it. they have good rates. good place to stay if you're looking for a decent deal and to be close to all the action. the room itself is pretty basic nothing to rave about.

There's a reason Paris rooms are generally priced much higher than other Harrah's properties (excepting Caesars). It's because Paris actually has redeeming qualities. Now, you won't find those qualities in the basic room, but, you will find them as soon as you get off the elevator.

Paris has some of the most fun clubs and restaurants. In particular, the dueling piano bar is a win on any given night. Good selection here, and fun crowds, but get there early. Also, Mon Ami Gabi, the strip-front French chain restaurant, is phenomenal, but that's for a different review. Another part of Paris' allure is that addicting crepe stand right outside the buffet. Mother of god.

Otherwise, Paris is a bit crammed because of all the attention it gets with visitors to the fake Eiffel Tower. The casino does not have a very winning flavor to it, although we did comfortably sit and play roulette one night for a good three hours and still finished inners. But I think that was more chance than a standard.

The other gripe about Paris is how cramped the buffet is. It simply does not have that wide-open, spacious dining room like the others. It feels more like a mini, turnpike rest stop. The food is really good, but the price is way too high and it simply isn't comfortable to navigate.

Overall, you're spending to stay here, and you're better off paying an additional $20-$30 a night to upgrade to a 4 or 5 star hotel with much better amenities.

Great location, so-so accommodations.

I know it's Vegas and they say you never sleep anyway, right?? But if you're by chance one of those rare persons that actually wants to sleep at some point you better be super drunk or on some kind of sleeping pills because the sound insulation in the rooms is nonexistent! 

You can experience such pleasures as everyone in the world walking down the hallway or the cranky mom yelling at her kids every second they're in the room. But that's not all, act now and you can also experience guy in the next bathroom!

Pros:
- Housekeeping was friendly and accommodating
- Center strip location
- Nice decor

Cons:
- Would not budge on the checkout time
- Mandatory $22 resort fee.
- Uncomfortable beds
- Noisy

Filthy. Finger prints and BLOOD on walls, broken door to the room, filth and black marks on the room chairs. We really thought the Paris was a top notch hotel prior to arrival but we're stunned with disappointment. Do yourself a favor and go down the street to the beautiful and luxurious Mandalay Bay. (It's cheaper too!) We ended up paying an extra $50 a night to upgrade to a clean room, I feel that that cost should've been waived due to the filth we experienced:( THE worst Vegas hotel I've seen. If zero stars was an option I'd rate this hotel as zero stars. Bummed

UPDATE: after the room upgrade it dawned on us that this must be a common tactic of the hotel to force their customers into paying more upon arrival.  They offered us the upgrade initially at additional cost and we declined. But upon inspecting the first room and its filth, upgrading was a must. Pretty shady business in my opinion. On the plus side the upgraded room was cleaner, but still worn down.  All of the photos I've posted are of the upgraded room! What a joke. This entire hotel needs a major renovation.
As mentioned previously, Mandalay Bay Is a much better value for what you spend, go there instead:) hope this helps y'all avoid the BS

PS: all photos are of the upgraded room

Even the manager of the reservations line could not rectify not making my reservation properly. Why do you need to talk to them only to be patched thru to the restaurant which never picks up the phone? Then you lose the reservation time you wanted because it takes 4 more calls to get thru. Stupidity and no loyalty to locals. Maybe the Vegas economy would be better if this town knew the meaning of customer service and especially to their locals who might actually return regularly and make recommendations to people who visit here on where they should go. I certainly won't ever recommend the customer service skills of ANY Ceasars  property until they fix their service issues!

Came here to eat at Mon Ami Gabi and walked through the hotel and casino to get there. Parking is easy...just a short walk from the garage to the casino. I didn't stay in the hotel, but the lobby area and casino are nice and of course the view of the eiffel tower is great. My favorite was the restaurant...so see my review of the food there. It's situated right across from the Bellagio so the view of the fountain show is perfection!

Great room, had a fun time staying at the Paris, right on the strip, love Mon Ami Gabi (the restaurant), didn't care so much for the other restaurants.  We didn't go up the tower this time, but the view is great from the top. Wasn't a fan of having to pay $14\/day for internet.
This hotel is in a great location, staff is extremely friendly, and I usually get comped rooms here. I will continue to stay here as long as the free rooms keep coming my way.

My husband and I just spent the weekend there. This was Mexican Independence Weekend in Vegas and there were a lot of good performers, shows and of course, the boxing match. We are from California and we decided to stay at the Paris as it is centrally located across from Bellagio and a short walk to Caesars. The room we stayed was a  suite in room 729P. It was a great big room--I felt like it was a small apartment. It was comfortable and came with the bare necessities. That is just it--the bare necessities. For the price we paid, it would have been nice to have some robes like many high end hotels offer and a makeup mirror. I was excited to have a vanity,  but the lighting was poor and so I didn't use it. The  safe was on the shelf in the closet and was so high that you cant see inside of it. Not very smart to put a safe so high--what if I was very short person? What if I was elderly and couldnt reach?  I also hate having a sink in my bedroom, it makes me feel like I am staying in a motel rather than a nice hotel. I decided I don't like Parisian decor-- flowery and outdated. We loved the Mon Amie Gabi Steakhouse--highly recommend it. But honestly, the drinks in the casino are watered down --I guess I shouldn't expect a good drink if I am getting it for free while I am gambling. But even at the bar, they didn't have a good bottle of tequila. If you think silver Patron is a good tequila, you don't know tequila. No anejos--not a complete  bar. We went over to Caesars and they did have good tequila--come on, not everyone drinks vodka and gin. But to be fair, the service was very good and always has been when we go to the bar at kiosk.   The workers are friendly.   The Fitness room was well equipped and had water and fresh fruit. Why we have to pay a resort fee to use it-- I don't know. They allowed one device for free WiFI--really, most people have their own device--Get with the 21st Century digital community!    Paris is expensive for what you get.  All in all, stay at the Paris if you want the basics, but high end, not really. It's comfortable and clean.

This hotel is really really pretty! I have been to Paris and the paintings on the main floor are pretty unreal! I have definitely stayed in nice hotels but it really does have an airy feel which I have found is hard to find at a lot of hotels in Vegas.

In A Nutshell:

-Paris Las Vegas Hotel & Casino is a solid hotel.
-Great, actually, excellent location as it sits right smack in the middle of the Las Vegas Strip.
-The check-in was flawless since I didn't have to stand in line by choosing to use their express terminals.
-5 minutes later I had room keys in hand.
-The "Burgundy" room had two queen beds, which were very comfortable to sleep in.
-The bathroom was bigger than average & had a seperate bath\/shower.
-The casino has plenty of table games, a decent amount of slots & a few shops\/restaurants.
-If you need to grab supplies, there is a CVS right next door.
-If you use Uber\/Lyft make sure you meet at the "North Door" by Anthony Cools.

Overall, this is a decent hotel stay in has good value & great location.  I'd stay again.
Can I give no star? No, too bad. My family and I were visiting all the hotel\/casinos at the strip and this one is the worst ever. Rude people, I mean employees.Thank God I was not staying there.

It's my first time staying at Paris, and it was pretty nice. I love how the hotel room elevator is very close to the main entrance, thus I don't have to weave through the casino to get to it. 

The room is pretty standard and spacious. The bathroom is pretty big, with a bath tub, standing shower, a sink and toilet. The a\/c unit works pretty well except when I try to raise the temperature over 72F, it starts giving out this burnt odor. Another thing is we were given a room that's connect to another room through a door, and whenever they're being loud, I can kind of hear. But it's not too bad considered I'm not in the room most of the time.

The location is also pretty good, consider it's like in the middle with Bellagio across the street and Cosmopolitan just diagonally across. 

There are several cafe down at the casino level, and it's nice to grab some pastry to go and head to the pool. The swimming pool here is pretty nice. I said no outside food allowed but I see everyone bring stuff in, and they're okay with it as long as it's not glass bottles and it doesn't contain alcohol. They put music on and there's a bar that serve greatttt frozen strawberry daquiri.

Also try their buffet, it's pretty good too.

First time staying here have enjoyed Mon Abi Gabi as well as the buffet at Le Village for breakfast is good.  The restaurant in the Eiffel tower is good but not great and not worth the price in my opinion go for a drink to check it out.  Check in was OK 10-15 minute wait.  They upgraded our room to honor a single king bed request which was nice, very pleased with the room and a decent view from the 31st floor.  Love the inside and walkways only issue I had was its very smoky in the casino area more smoky than most other nearby Casinos.
The view from on top of the Eiffel tower is amazing. Definitely go up right before the Bellagio fountains perform and you will get a spectacular view.

This place absoloutely gorgeous inside! the entire time you are walking through you feel lik you are outside in a french village and there are so many delicious little eateries. There's not a lot of modern shops like other hotels.

Casino: very small and looks kinda boring. not sure if this is the place to gamble because everyone's face just looks so traumatized. either they won a lot of moolas or they just lost everything...

Hotel: Everything was clean and we enjoyed using the flat screen t.v. while getting ready.   

Recommended:

1)The Eiffel Towel replica is the best thing to look at at night.
2) Buy on of those tour eiffel drinks or the big paris ball as a souvenir!

I recently stayed here for a conference and I am not a fan of the rooms. They are old, dank, dark, depressing.  The casino is ok, and the restaurants are good, but I will never stay here again.  I had to pay for wifi in my room, but it was free in the rest of the hotel....  I ordered room service for breakfast and they got my order wrong. For lunch it came cold.

                       .         .  .    .            !!!!        .       .                   .         .             .
                                    .                 !!!!!       .    .   .          .                     .      .

Oh Gay Pareez [sic]! Voulez vous coucher avec moi ce soir! Giuchie     
Giuchie, ya ya dada (Hey hey hey)--Yeah that's how me and Christiana do it when we're getting durrrty up in hurrr in the fine Paris Hotel and Casino.
            _______________________________________ 
I'm a simpleton when I gamble. I don't like to  think. "Yo 7, yo 11, yo mama WTF? I don't get craps!" "I'm the 'anchor,' I have 12, dealer shows 6 top card, and I don't hit? WTF?" I like to sit there with my Malibu and coke  and just pull the handle. Don't hate on the Malibu---it's a superstitious and FREE, albeit embarrassing thing that I drink when I gamble. Even 'Amelie,' our French-attired cocktail waitress gets a chuckle out of this. 
          ________________________________________  
Set in an idyllic location, in a courtyard backdrop away from the tables and the Eiffel Tower , sits the high limit slot areas. During a four hour stretch on a $5 machine, I nailed a
                                    77777     777777     7777777 
                                   7    77       7    77        7       77 
                                         77             77                 77  
                                         77             77                77    
                                        77             77                77   

And lost it all at a ahemm, Gentleman's Club. C'mon now, we's in Vegas, baby!   
           __________________________________
All in all, Paris is a wonderful casino. A bit on the dark\/romantic, smoky side just like the REAL Paris. Buffets are not my cup de the (that's the French version, homeys) so I skip all together. Rooms are well, they're just rooms. The pool area? Ehh. Not after visiting Men-get-lay Bay. Otherwise, Pareez is in a central location and offers a wonderful stay. Giuchie, Giuchie, ya ya dada (da-da-da)
                 ______________________________________
Didn't stay here, but checked it out as a visitor. The theme was pretty cool.

It was a horrible experience! Upon enter the room, we discovered some thousand years old stains in the tub & bed sheets. If it's something small we can just let that go but it was so obvious! Try to get someone to assist never easy, I think it's faster if I ran down to the room service grab a bed sheet and change it myself! Will get to the power outage in a bit! 

No hot water in the shower & water pressure took a dump for three days! Nobody care to fix it neither! We checked in around 8pm on Oct 31st, 2016. Soon found out there is no hot water in the shower at 10pm. Contacted the front desk, they just gave us a run around, listening to their boring on hold music for the longest time, transferred to few different department and finally told us someone will be there within 20 minutes.. Yeah right.. Someone knock on the door 3 hours later. Without any repair done, just told us to turn on hot water in the sink and tub for 15 minutes and we will have hot water. That doesn't seems to work, the guy said he will go get parts and that was the end of it.. End up we had to shower in North Pole! 
Repeated the same cycle again on the second night.. Contact front desk, put on hold, wait for someone to show up and that was 3am! Replaced the valve and We finally can take hot shower now.. That's a yay!

Yay too soon! Next morning power outage at around 9:30am and nobody knows what's going on! Hotel staffs walking around in the pitch black hall way with the flash light from their mobile phone telling everyone to calm down. Luckily we live on the 5\/F, without any backup lighting anywhere, walking flights of stairs with only the flash light from our cell phones. No sign no indications of where the stairs lead to. Finally see the light from the emergency exit, it was the loading area in the back of the hotel or some sort. Walk around the whole building try to get to the front desk but it was all blocked off. No one can enter the hotel until further notice. We can't get our luggage until 11pm. 
Will not recommend anyone to stay at Paris Las Vegas Hotel & Casino ever, even if they offer free room!

Pros: 
Location is center strip, close to everything. PH next door, Bellagio across the street. There's a new Walgreens at the corner of The Strip\/Harmon in case you need anything.

Clean, spacious basic room w\/big chair, sofa, coffee table and a desk. 

Clean, spacious bathroom with separate tub and shower

Cons:
Bed isn't great- you can feel the springs
Flat screen TV is to the left of the bed, so you'd have to watch it from your oh so quaint French styled couch-lol- not a big deal, but odd

If you self park, prepare for a trek to registration all the way at the front of the hotel.

got a great deal through signing up for their emails and Cyber Monday;would return again

I thought the rooms were fine. Just a typical Las Vegas hotel room... until.... I woke up COVERED in bug bites! On the first night my girlfriend woke up in her bed with what looked like flea bites. I made fun of her saying her dog at home was dirty. Then the second night.... I became covered in red itchy bumps ALL OVER. I have sensitive skin so the bug bites ended up giving me a rash as well. All over my chest, head and body. It was DISGUSTING!!! Both of us, in TWO different beds, were covered in bug bites. Fleas? Bed bugs? I don't know but I will NOT be coming back here.

I didn't bother to complain to the hotel because the room was comped any ways but it was disgusting nonethless. =X

They have a little bar with cafe seating right before you walk into the street scape. They had 1\/2 price martini's. I thought that you had to order 2 of the same. So I got 4. Two of each. When I got mine it burnt the hair out of my nose. The pomegranate was there just for color. I asked for a couple of olives because I was getting hungry. They were huge and very tasty. This is a great place to people watch. Some old fart parked his walker next to our table and proceeded to talk about baseball for the next half hour. I had no idea what he was yaking about? But he was amusing. The service was great. Next time I am staying at this hotel. They have everything.

This was my first place to gamble, and I was in awe - here's why:

The roof is painted like the sky at dusk, which is pretty cool.
The games are fun and typical of all of the other casinos on the strip,
The place is lit such that you have zero clue as to what time of day or night it is... kinda crazy.

Overall, interesting and just what I expected of Las Vegas.

Excellent service and great hotel. We have a 2 day stay and really enjoyed it.
One of the best hotels in LV.
The room was very clean and comfortable. 2 bedrooms 3 bathrooms.
We liked the breakfast as well.

Staff at reception desk was not friendly during check-in, and Jenny was downright hostile when I approached with a package I needed assistance with late at night after the business center was closed. (I did call ahead and someone else told me it was ok. I had an event that evening and an early flight the next day so it was not an option for me to go to the business center anyway). 

My room was on the fourth floor and the view to the tower and the pool area was obscured by a tree. Housekeeping was weak. I noticed a dirty sock (not mine) under the bed and an earplug (also not mine) which remained there during my stay despite them supposedly cleaning daily. The tissues ran out halfway through my stay and did not get replaced when housekeeping cleaned the bathroom. It made me wonder how thorough their procedures are. Obviously not very...

The room also lacked outlets. There was only one available by the desk and the other was on an open wall, so I had to set my phone on the floor while it charged. There was only one towel hook in the bathroom and it was nowhere near the shower. 

I guess if you like gambling and smoking (or breathing second hand smoke) this place would be ideal. I was there for a business event and it was frustrating walking so far to the conference center, especially with all the tourists just casually strolling around. 

If I return to Vegas on my own accord, I would not stay there again.

Stayed here for a long overdue Vegas run and concert with a good Friend. Perfect base of operations to re-explore the Strip. Incredible restaurants everywhere! Ramsey's Steak in the house. Banging tables, best run I've ever had. Chelsea, our dealer, was just perfect in all regards. 92Â° in the shade and a light desert rain shower made it so humid, that cocktails by the pool constituted a medical necessity. Too hot to enjoy all the restaurants we wanted to hit. (Ramsey, Lotus of Siam, etc.) Cause for a redo. Coming home with about a Grand to the good, how did that happen? I actually feel a little guilty I didn't leave it all there, as usual. I believe I'll get over it, however.

Someone needs to tell the interior designers of this place to go back to design school. Who the hell puts a dresser in the middle of the room?!

Besides that minor flaw, I always enjoy my stays here at Paris. One of my friends has the hook up here so this is our official residence for our annual Vegas trips. 

I think the distance from the front doors to the hotel elevators is really short and therefore convenient when you need to:

1. use the bathroom for #1 or #2 or puke 
2. pass out on the bed after a long night of partying 

On our recent trip, we had a semi suite. We had a foyer (perfect place to put a roll away) and a wet bar. There were 2 bathrooms; one with a shower and one with a huge jacuzzi. 

The dresser in the middle of the room mentioned earlier housed the TV. When I opened the dresser, I assumed the TV was a flat screen and was able to rotate so you can watch TV in the sitting area. Not the case; still had a big ol clunky set.

The location on the strip is smack dab in the middle so everything is easily accessible. You can catch the Bellagio show across the street. PH is right next door and Ceasar's is pretty close. 

The staff is really helpful; one of the cleaning staff noticed I kept leaving the room to get ice to fill up the sink for our liqs and decided to give me a plastic so I can make less trips. 

Good place to stay in Vegas.

I recently stayed here for the first time and liked it quite a bit.  I stayed in a suite which was so beautiful.  The casino's ceilings were painted like a sky on a summer day which added a lot to the ambience.  The shops were just blah.  There were a lot more restaurants than shops which is fine if you're in the mood to eat.  I was looking to shop so I turned around pretty quickly.  There's a mall right across the street called the Miracle Mall Shops, which has a lot of variety of stores.  The food in the room service department was awesome.  Order something that has lots of fries as a side dish.  Trust me.  It's not my favorite hotel on the strip but I did like it.

Stayed here for 3 nights while in Vegas. Nice hotel for a reasonable price on the strip. Several places to grab a quick bite to eat or to sit down to enjoy a meal within the hotel. The casino was cool, the dealers were super friendly. Stayed Friday through Monday and it wasn't really too crowded so that was nice and less smoky then some of the other casinos. Rooms were clean and nice, pretty standard for a hotel. Room service was delicious and in my opinion not too expensive. Would definitely stay here again when in Vegas!

Pros:  nicely themed hotel; great casino; perfect location; well appointed rooms; rooms are clean and spacious; pretty good buffet

Cons:  prices can be steep and Caesars entertainment tries to nickel and dime you for everything; rooms facing the strip will hear very loud music from the club chateau (which plays on weekends until 3am-- I found that annoying); pool and gym close early

Overall, I would give the hotel 3.5 stars (rounded up to 4).  Paris is a good mid range option-- though I believe there are superior midrange options on the strip including vdara and mirage.

We have stayed here since the hotel opened in 2001?  It has changed over the years, mainly the level of service and effort put forth by the employees ever since Harrahs' now called Caesars Entertainment, has taken over.  It's a great location, right in the middle of the strip and the rooms now called "premier view" rooms overlook the Bellagio Fountains, one of my favorite FREE things about LV.  They have many spacious suites with whirlpool tubs and sitting areas we usually opt for now instead of the more expensive basic room with the "premier view"  Your rate here depends drastically on how much gaming you do and the points accumulated on your Total Rewards card.  Show your card at the hotel owned restaurants and shops to gain additional points.  Your points can also be used towards your hotel bill.

We really enjoyed our stay at Paris. The burgundy room was nice. There is a great selection of cafes and restaurants in and around the hotel. We also found it to be very quiet compared to other locations and got a good night's rest. We were on the side with no view and overlooking rooftops which may have helped. The only reason I'm not giving it five stars is the lack of cleanliness and updates at the pool. We arrived after it opened and were there a few hours sunbathing. The water was very dirty with a lot of dirt and debris. We chose not to go in for that reason. The patio itself is in dire need of power washing and the trash bins, particularly those for cigarettes etc., were overflowing, which was what we noticed the prior evening when we took a peek at the pool. They had still not been emptied. We did not locate one, but it would be nice to have a water fountain to fill our own bottles at no cost instead of buying bottled water which is expensive and not environmentally friendly. What we did like about this pool was that it was peaceful and quiet overall, especially in the morning. It was a good place to just relax and did not have that club vibe.

AMAZING how all the staff here speak fluent French!!!! Not really :)

I just don't like how claustrophobic the place feels!  They have a painted ceiling that looks like the sky and the feel of walking down a street in Paris.  Very closed in feeling that I do not like.  Very similar to how they did NY NY, trying to give you the feel of being there, but just too closed in for my liking.

Otherwise I did like the red guest room we stayed in!  It was clean and spacious.  Careful of the marble floors in the bathroom though, I found it to be slippery... 

Good location on the middle of the strip.

I've never really liked this place.  The gaming area is small and the lackluster rooms leave much to be desired.  The pin-striping everywhere makes me dizzy and completely irritates the shit out of me.

I'll reserve the 1 star rating for some other places down the street, because even though I hate this place,.....it could be worse.  That second star could easily be a half, though.

Stay somewhere else, even if the room is comp'd.

Stayed for a single night.

The room was actually decorated with quite the modern style. The room has an iHome, so bring your ipod to hook your room up with some tunes.

I really enjoyed the pool as its located in the shadow of the Eiffel tower. The pool is quite large in diameter, but only 3.5 feet deep throughout.

UGH NEVER AGAIN. 

We stayed in a "supposedly" suite. YOU CALL THAT A SUITE?! Paris, you need to get your eyes checked and redo those rooms. I will never stay here again. 

CONS:
-terrible customer service
-no view whatsoever
-boring, small casino.


The only ONLY good thing about this hotel is that it's right across Bellagio and smack dab right in the middle of the strip. The only good thing. Sad really. 

oh yeah, no free wifi. terrible.

Best joint in Vegas I've stayed at so far. The casino is great - the waitresses kept the drinks flowin and my gambling fever rolling. exc. but pricey resturants for you foodies.
The Eifel tower was great and the view of the Bellagio light show was fantastic from up there.

Beautiful room, all hotel employees were polite and friendly, food was priced as expected considering it is Las Vegas. I purchased the buffet of buffets, well worth the price. Loved the whole experience!

This is a great, central location with a lot going on. The Casino is solid, the rooms are comfortable and well priced and the crowd here was not too rowdy so we were able to relax when in the room. We had a great view and the staff was very helpful. The room was a little worn but it had everything we needed for the price and location.  No real complaints.

We stayed the last week of October for a gaming tournament. I really wish I could remember the lady who checked us in and out, she was such a sweetheart. She explained to us all the details of our room and our itinerary for our tournament. After checking in, we went to the creperie downstairs and I got the chicken pesto crepe and my husband go the monte cristo, Both were very delicious! The views were incredible and i loved our room. Thank you to all the staff for a great weekend!

Ah, Pari'! I have been to vegas multiple times but Paris had not been built yet. Now that I have visited I have to stay there! They have all the Paris landmarks like the Champs Elysee,  Arc de Triomphe and of course the Eiffel Tower. They also have pattiseries, brasseries, and shoppes catering to Parisian splendor. I did not have time to see everything but they leave you wanting more as you wander down the "streets" and look up at the painted "sky".

I stay here once in a while when I come to Vegas, I like the location between the other casinos. I don't play here, because out of all the Total Rewards Casinos, this one is one of the tighest on there slots. The inside of the casino is very pretty and the staff is super nice. The drink servers on the floor are very few and slow. I'm rating this on the hotel, the gaming is another story.

hell to the NO!...good thing it was a free room!  it was freakin smokey, stinky and dirty!
SUCH A  small room! very uncomfortable bed!

the staff were soo unfriendly!

hated how the hotel was set up!

I really don't think there was good ventilation here...very smokey!

really unhappy, i'm just fortunate we didn't pay for the room...so disappointed with this hotel, never again!

It's small but it'll do. The room was just OK, but if you're spending mass time sitting in your room then you shouldn't be in Vegas anyway. Maybe skip Vegas and go to your grandma's house, I'm sure she'd love to sit around and do nothing with you. Maybe she'll make you a sandwich and you can watch Murder She Wrote. 

For those who are in Vegas to actually DO Vegas, here are my highlights: 

Pro #1: LOCATION. It's right in the middle of the strip, if you're planning all kinds of debauchery across the touristy part of town you're in the right place. You are positioned perfectly for a quick cab ride or a chill walk to anywhere else on the strip. Restaurants, clubs, bars, shopping, you're right in the center. I loved THEhotel at Mandalay Bay a few weeks prior but frankly it's at the very end of the strip, those cab rides pile up quick son. 

Pro #2: The audio being played in the bathrooms. Yea that's right, go take a leak and listen carefully to what's playing in the can. It's an audio lesson that teaches you "helpful phrases for your Vegas trip" in French. It is Paris after all, why not learn some French right? 

Ladies, you will learn how to say helpful comments such as: 
"I shaved my legs for this?" 
"If my husband calls, I'm not here. If the pool boy calls, I'm here." 
"Has anyone seen my panties?" 

Fellas, take note: 
"You know what? Your clothes would look great on my bedroom floor." 
"How do I get this glitter off my clothes?" 
"Oh bleep, where is my wedding ring?" 

And many more. The phrases sound a lot sexier in French too. 

I'm not blown away by the rooms but there was a bed and a shower, all you really need. The main casino and shops are small in comparison to others in the area but they're nice, and Mon Ami Gabi is a tremendous restaurant located on site. Delicious affordable wines, fantastic food, AND it's the only friggen bar in Vegas I could find with Fernet! 

I dig it. Nothing amazing but it's positioned right where I need it to be. That plus Fernet, I'm gold.

The economy is really showing at the Paris. They no longer have any nightlife whatsoever outside f the little open bar in the center. RisquÃ© has closed and I really liked it there. 

Things are just starting to look really run down. It made me feel sad.

I have a lot of mixed feelings about this hotel... it's a nice place with ambiance, reasonably priced with a great location on the strip. But it's also cheesy and the customer service is touch and go.

We stayed for one night [stayed with friends off the strip for the rest of our trip] and when I booked the room online, my friend and travel partner called the hotel to check what kind of pillows they use. She's very allergic to goose down feathers, and they told her that those types of pillows were only provided upon request. When we checked in, she asked the front desk person the same thing and got the same answer. So we got into our room, changed and immediately went out to the strip for a few hours. 

When we got back for the night, my friend got into bed to relax and noticed ALL the pillows [except for the decorative pillows] contained goose down feathers. Not only that, but it took an attendant over an hour to remove the pillows from the room and replace them. 

We had planned on sending a strongly worded email to the higher-ups at Harrah's, but I found out our $90 room service breakfast and all of our pool drinks were comped. We figured that was fair enough.

We stayed in the red room; it was quite nice, on the 26th floor with a decent view of Bally's, the Wynn and the Encore. I loved the bathroom - full-length mirror on the door, double sinks and a separate bathtub. The beds could have been more comfortable with more blankets though. And the air in the rooms was even more dry than the air outside. 

The pool was also a lot smaller than I expected. Most Vegas resorts have bigger pools and often more than one, but they only had the one and it was a weird round shape. The water was also quite cold, even for Vegas in late May. Poolside service was good though, very prompt and they service nice big drinks in souvenir cups.

The crepe place was amazing - it was in an awkward location, but it didn't really matter because the food was super yummy. And don't bother with the giant souvenir Eiffel Tower drinks - they put a lot of cheap tequila in them and they're awkward and difficult to carry. 

I would probably stay here again, because of the location or price, but only if I couldn't afford something better.

The architecture on site is magnificent for picture taking and posing! I did not stay at the hotel; however, I did try their buffet. I was not pleased nor did I enjoy it. I was told by word of mouth that the Paris Buffet was the best buffet. WRONG! It was small and the place seemed clustered up with the paint job and decorations. The atmosphere did not seem calming but chaotic. My sister and I couldn't wait to get out of there. The only reason we stayed to eat was because we paid for it. The only thing that tasted appetizing was the pizza and salad. If there is a line for the buffet, do not bother waiting. Just go right across to the Bellagio and your appetite will be satisfied for a few dollars more.

Casino wise, it is okay. Every time I visit the Paris for a hand of blackjack, the tables are dead. The design on the inside though is pretty nifty and I love the blue cloud like ceilings. 

This review is only based on the casino and the buffet. I have never stayed at the hotel.

The score is raised up a bit but well deserved in regards to comfort, views, and its location in the strip.

-- Let's start with the bad: 

Paris is a bit old. Though the hotel was built recently in the last  two decades, some room designer screwed up by putting a giant armoire in the front of the room. This person likely thought that giant fat CRT TVs would live on forever - but alas, this isn't a Motel 6. 

This person also screwed up because they thought TVs wouldn't get much larger. 

They did.

What you have, therefore, is a giant armoire with a closet on the left and right flanking the center door which now houses an out of place mini-fridge. The TV has been unceremoniously moved to the left of the furniture-piece and mounted on the wall above a writing table, putting it in direct line-of-sight with the left bed and making the person on the right bed slightly unhappier. 

Issue number two is that to give you the Paris feel, they hang many things on the wall. Unfortunately, when putting electrical on the wall, you can either conceal the wires inside a headboard for a flush, yet removable option, flush the wires inside the wall entirely, or put raceways on the wall.

You get raceways. Actually lots of raceways.

There's a raceway under the writing table and one on each side of the bed. Rather ghetto-fies the experience a bit but it's not absolutely terrible.

-- On the plus side: 

The beds are very comfortable with 3 pillows per bed. The bathrooms have marble floors and are very roomy with a nice tub and a separate stand-alone shower.

The mini-fridge, while out of place, lets you stock up on drinks without having to pay obscene  Vegas prices. 

We had views of the Bellagio fountains and the Eiffel tower and the pool. A+

Walking distance to everything on the strip and direct access to Bally's and thus direct access to the monorail.

-- On the neutral:

Only two Wi-Fi devices\/room.

The room itself was not amazing. It was not the room that we booked. We had reserved a king size and were given two queens instead. Not a great start to a romantic weekend with my husband. There were stains on the carpet with no extra amenities. There are lots of food options in the hotel, it was centrally located and a reasonable price.

A Frech in PAris, in Vegas...this is America for you. I like the top floor where I stayed, great rooms and views. Hotel was just nice. I am not sure about the faux sky and the faux everything but that makes it extra kitsch. Watching the tourists take pictures like they were in PAris crack me up every single time. The hotel also had my favorite food hangout at the strip level so that makes it even better. Not the best hotel but a great deal for a French in Vegas

My girlfriend and I booked a room here, along with a bunch of family for my Dad's birthday. We managed to get a decent deal on the rooms. The service was excellent, the room was okay, and the food was rather mediocre and grossly overpriced. More details on all of this below.

The main reason I'm giving the hotel such a low rating was because of the cleanliness of the hotel itself. The whole place had a little bit of an old, dark and dingy feel to it. But the room service bowl that sat outside of the door of the room next to mine for over a day, the hole in the wall in the hallway, and the rusted shower fixtures really put things over the top for me. I definitely expected more from a very prominent hotel on the strip. 

Now, onto food. Where else but Yankee Stadium can you spend $9 for two sodas? Apparently, it's Las Vegas. Specifically, the Paris hotel. I'm sure glad I ate dinner before we arrived the first night. The breakfast buffet was equally sticker shocking - nearly $50 for the two of us, and most of the food was extremely greasy. I must say, they did have a very fresh and high quality selection of fruit, when they managed to keep it stock. We also ate at the noodle and wanton bar (very tasty by the way), which also costed us almost $50 for two small entrees and an appetizer. After having dinner that night, we decided not to eat any more meals in the hotel. There are plenty of restaurants in the shopping center next door that are more reasonably priced.

On the plus side, the casino has a nice variety and my dad won $1200, which was a great thing to happen on his birthday. The service was most excellent - didn't have any issues at all there.

Would I come back? Probably not. There are many hotel options on and off strip, and after walking through a few others (particularly Aria), I think we'll stay elsewhere next time.

I thought this would be perfect hotel for Mother's Day weekend due to the beautiful decor the hotel has. Unfortunately, the room was less than desirable. The wallpaper was peeling off, the interior decor was so outdated. To make it even better we couldn't keep our blinds open due to moth season. The resort fee wasn't worth it, too pricey for nothing. I rather pay more for better hotel, or pay the same at hotel that has taken time to renovate rooms.

I had to call Housekeeping twice to see if they would come up and remove room service food from the hallway. Half eaten food left in the hallway for hours at a time turns my stomach and makes me wonder how the Hotel isn't infested with all kinds of vermin. There is a stereotype saying that French people are rude. I wonder if the people who created this stereotype came to Paris Las Vegas, because it is completely correct here. Employees seem to be annoyed by the guests and they let you know it with eye rolling, lip smacking, and voice tone. What happened to hospitality? Pool only open until 8 pm, really? No outside drink allowed at the pool, really? Pool only gets cleaned once per day, so get used to swimming with plastic wrappers, beer cans, cigarette butts, and whatever else the wind catches and throws in! I have a bigger tv in my bathroom at home. Pay for WiFi, not even a $50 room @ Holiday Inn makes you pay for WiFi...
Gorgeous hotel!! Inside and out! Great restaurants!

We went to Las Vegas the first week in June 2011 for a convention.  It was held at Paris, so for convenience we stayed there.  They offered a discounted rate of $139, and we upgraded to a suite for another $70. I thought the suite was large and really nice. The bathroom was amazing.  We had a whirlpool tub, separate shower, his and her sinks, and yes...even a bidet.  

The service here was great.  Everyone went above and beyond.  When we first got to our room, the safe was locked shut.  They sent up two security guards, asked for our ID...professional and honest.  The concierge got us great tickets to Jersey Boys.  We had lost two items on our last day...a rather expensive ring of my husband's, and rather expensive sunglasses of mine.  Lost and Found, both at the Convention (ballroom), and for the hotel was extremely helpful.  They made an announcement in the convention...the ring was returned to us within a couple hours.  I left the hotel without my sunglasses, but gave her my cell number.  I had a call at the airport with the great news, and they sent my sunglasses to my home.  

We didn't get to experience much of the food here, as we like to go out and about.  I had breakfast outside at Mon Ami Gabi.  Great view and people watching, and the spinach and asparagus quiche was delish.  La Cave has wine and liquor for purchase.  Cafe Belle Madeline has some amazing desserts.  I had the Tiramisu which comes in a chocolate cup.  The Sugar Factory is a cute shop\/restaurant with anything from T-shirts to celebrity lollipops to ice cream.  They also serve food.  

We don't gamble much, so I don't have much to comment on there.  I think maybe $50 in a slot machine.  Borrring.  

Loved the stay here.  The location is perfect for us...across from the Bellagio and Cosmopolitan... and near Caesars Forum shops.

This hotel embodies the saying "oldie but goodie." Even though it opened a little earlier than Venetian or Bellagio it feels a bit grittier. I think that's what gives this hotel is character but not in a downtown Vegas way. In fact, it still is a solid choice for couples who are looking to get away and is a nice place to stay with your friends.  Paris Vegas hotel house the popular Mon Ami Gabi restaurant where you can chow down on their delicious french onion soup and munch on their frites while having the best view of the bellagio fountains. 

Paris also offers the Eiffel Tower Experience where you get to go up their replica Eiffel tower. I've never been but I heard from all my friends who got proposed there that it was worth going up especially since it offers a 360 degrees view on their observation deck. 

The dealers here are rather warm at most of the craps and card game tables with possibly an exception to the baccarat. You are better served in the the High Limit room.

The rooms here are okay and if you get upgraded to one of their "suites" keep in mind all their room is allocated to the closet and bathroom. The bedroom area is average compared to the other four star hotels on the strip. Beds are a bit below average in comfort. 

Rates are rather low but you can score a cheaper discount ($25 off) by using the hoteltonight app using the code mrhee3.

I am not a high maintenance gal although I do enjoy a very nice\/ clean hotel room. Unfortunately the Paris hotel is an older hotel therefore it's outdated and not the cleanest. I've stayed at the hard rock hotel and even though it's not on the strip, I would probably stay there again. The 4 stars I am giving this hotel is purely on location. Being right on the strip was so nice because of the easy access to everything. You can walk anywhere and not have to worry about jumping in a taxi (unless you decide to go to downtown Vegas). We got room service one night and the guy who delivered was nice. The food was expensive but it wasn't bad food, so for the fact we were lazy and got room service, we paid the price. In closing..I won't stay at Paris again. I'll try another hotel next time I visit.

Oh how I miss the glory days of the "theme" casinos. For me, the theme ones will always be the most fun. And Paris is one of the best of the theme places.

This is definitely one of the properties where you absolutely must take a stroll around inside. And going to the top of the Eiffel Tower is a nice view. There's some good crepe and French bakery-type places. The buffet is ok. There is lots of great viewing of the Bellagio Fountains. Etc., etc.

The rooms are pretty great. They show their age a bit, but they are of good size and have a nice decor. For the price, the rooms here are a great value.

In the end, though, it will always be the theme, and their total embrace of it, that draws me here.

DO NOT BOOK A ROOM HERE!!! Please read before you do!!!

I wish I could actually not even give this place 1 star. It doesn't even deserve that. Coming into the valet took 30 minutes for someone to even walk up to our car. Once someone did, I asked him for help with our luggage. He screamed across the parking lot to someone else far away right in my face. When the bell boy came over I asked how long it would take to get our bags to the room he said 20-25 minutes. Our friends were meeting for dinner and we were already now running behind, so I kindly told him never mind. He rolled his eyes and stormed off. Rude. 

Now the check in. Oh dear lord. 50 people in line and 4 check in people, who by the way talk down to you like your an idiot. Took another 45 minutes to get the room keys. An hour and 15 minutes later! By the time we finally walk all the way to our room which by the way is a 10 minute walk with all the luggage, our KEYS DONT WORK. Have to walk all the way back down the hall, down the elevator and all the way back down to the lobby to get new keys, not once BUT TWICE IN ONE DAY!!!!! This is so frustrating, because the check in desk is not right around the corner!!! It's a mile away! My friends had the same issue with their keys. Seriously what hotel has such an issue with providing keys that work! Especially when the rooms are so far from the lobby!  Charles (a check in person) was super rude, no sympathy, no customer service and a complete ass. The employees are miserable and lack people skills. First time to Vegas and I wouldn't wish this place on my worst enemy. This place is dirty, run down, and disgusting. Smells like a jail cell. DO NOT COME HERE FOR THE HOTEL!!!! 

Water in bathroom doesn't even get hot.

This review is for the restaurants, casino and shopping. We spent a few hour's one day inside Paris. I thought it was so nice inside, the architecture of the Eiffel tower was amazing. Once inside it feels like you are on a street in Paris. 

The guest registration area is beautiful with gorgeous crystal chandeliers sparkling. The cobblestone streets lined with cafes, bakery's, and shopping. I bought a few thing's while here. They even had two wine and cheese shops with to die for baguette's. Now, the desserts, wow they were plentiful and delicious. 

The Eiffel tower restaurant is very nice, we did not eat here but you are able to go up the elevator and check it out. When you get out of the elevator you literally are standing directly in front of the kitchen. It was very cool. The restaurant has great views of the city, romantic, nice bar and the food prices were not bad at all. I wanted to dine here as it was so pretty but the menu is limited and I did not see anything I cared for. 

Great place to check out, as we enjoyed our afternoon lunch, shopping and playing a bit. Loved the soft blue sky, made you feel like you were outside in this beautiful city.

I was mesmerized by the larger than life Eiffel Tower greeting me as I walked into Paris hotel.  When you walk in it actually does feel a little like a Parisian getaway, cigarette smoke and all! 
We stayed at Paris simply because we got a really good group rate through a sports club that we were traveling with.  Things are seen through a kinder set of eyes when you're getting a really good deal for something!  
The hotel itself is nice.  The Paris theme is carried throughout the hotel and casino but not too much in the cheap rooms that we stayed in.  A lot of the stores and cafes started with "Le"... I guess if you put the word Le in front of a word, it makes it French.  Either way, it was fun to play along for the weekend.  The lobby was nice, the hotel was clean and restaurant that we ate breakfast at, Le CafÃ© Ile St. Louis, was good.  
Our room was a slight step above average.  There were no bells or whistles but at least the bed was comfy, the room was clean, and there was plenty of space for us and our things.
The highlight of Paris hotel was Chateau Nightclub!!  A swanky nightclub with great music and a beautiful terrace situated underneath the arch of the Eiffel tower!  A MUST SEE!!
Overall, I love the location of the Paris Hotel and Casino.  If I do stay at this hotel again, I think I'll splurge a little to see what some of the other rooms have to offer.

FAQ

Q: I heard that this is the best smelling Casino\/Resort in Las Vegas. Is this true?
A: Oh, absolutely. Between the hours of 5.00am and 11.00am, there is the glorious smell of stale cigarettes, carpet cleaner, freshly baked croissants and strong coffee. All of that surrounded by the mesmerizing din of slot machine noise. A perfect environment when you're stumbling towards your room at the Flamingo at 5.45am, hoping to God that someone is awake in the room and will open the door for you.

Q: Wow! This is the sort of classy place that I'd like to throw-up in!
A: Absolutely.

Q: I'm poor, I can't do Paris.
A: Help Las Vegas get even closer to replicating Paris by being a Street Urchin. There's lots of bread in the bread carts and the bakeries that line the "cobble-stoned" streets. Steal loaves of bread! Distribute them to the poor! Power to the people!

FYI ... The Paris Las Vegas security doesn't take kindly to your Quasi-Communist\/Robin Hood-esque antics.

This was probably my 4th time staying in the wonderful paris hotel, I will say that the rooms themselves and very nice, but we got a horrible view, the room service food was good, even though it took an hour for a continental breakfast, i will say the lobby and casino area is very pretty, even though the slot machines suck, and that the people are friendly. 

I would only go back here if I was just sleeping there... but then again, it is vegas, and that is all you do in your hotel room anyway.

Valet crashed our Van and admitted it. We had to wait for 1 hours to fill out paperwork, we still paid out parking, it took two weeks to get a response from them, they tried to short change us for a rental car by giving use $85 for 2 days.(they didn't crash a small coup) we took our car to a local shop and they said it was $100 too high. By the way this was on Mother's Day with 15 month twins waiting in the Van.  All of this, no compensation and we our out $100(we are taking the van to our own shop!
Low class casino

I have stayed at other casino\/hotels on the Strip but Paris is the best. The rooms are very nice. I especially liked the two closets and the refrigerator. We ate at Mon Ami Gabi and the food was very good. But the best thing about Paris is that the high ceilings and the air system combine to make it the least smoky casino on the strip.

Nothing too bad to say:
Fun time.
Good pool area.
Room was nice.
Staff was friendly enough.
Dealers were cool.
Harrah's owned so I added to my Total Rewards.
Centrally located.

Only one bad bartender in sports bar who didn't want to serve me because I wasn't betting max on EVERY hand.  Told me that I was in Vegas like I was some back woods hick who ventured out into the big city.

Only stayed here on a few nights for one visit, but the team is very nice.  The restaurants are delicious.  The Casino has a great variety of game play.  The best part of the Paris has go to be the location.  This hotel and casino is strategically located across from the Bellagio, which is basically right near the middle of the strip.  I was here with a buddy of mine who was having a work function and we were able to walk out of the hotel and hit many other hotels just by walking!  I was impressed with the value of the rooms as well.  It sounded like it wasn't a very expensive stay.  It was even better for me since I stayed on his dime, haha.  The rooms looked to have been updated recently which is always a nice touch and the new beer garden overlooks the strip and has a menu full of delicious comfort food to munch on.  If you don't have a specific place to stay, I would definitely recommend staying at the Paris.

We didnt stay at Paris this trip but we do love love love their buffet.  Their food choices are the best of the Las Vegas buffets, in our opinion, as they dont serve the standard fare. They serve foods such as assorted cheeses, crepes, mussels, lox, stewed cherries, quiche and their desserts are divine! The crepe line does demand dedication as it can get quite long, however, so try to go at an off time. Get the 24 hour buffet pass for five Vegas buffets--you'll be glad you did.

This casino is one of my favorite to gamble in...
(great dealers, beautiful venue, kind of feels like you're outside, airy)
Suites are awesome... 
Rooms are average...
Street image is fantastic...
Pool is pretty nice... 
Not usually where I'll stay but I'll be back to gamble!!!

It was a serious disapointment.  I would either pay more for a better hotel or less for the same hotel.  My room was a standard double queen room, it smelled like smoke from the vents i guess, and randomly at night every hour, it sounded like someone was taking a 15 minute shower.  it sounded like we were by the ice machine, but we weren't, so I have no idea what this running water sound was.  i didnt complain to font desk, because thats just annoying both ways.  it just sucked.  anyway, if i expected this maybe i'd stay at flamingo instead for cheaper with same quality, or just go somewhere nice like venetian.

***** Review is For Valet Parking Only*****

I do pretty much every parking valet in Las Vegas. Paris hotel has always been the WORST waiting time.....15 to 20 minutes in average between the time you give your ticket and the time they delivery your car.... WHY ??????? all other hotels have an average of 5 minutes... I only go to this valet if I am late to my appointments. Some people are not tourist and have to work.  PLEASE FIX IT !!!!!!!

Very nice hotel..Nice staff specially in  valet parking.. there are a lot of restaurant and Cafe inside the hotel. the price is good and the best thing is the hotel is right on strip and you don't need to drive a lot :)
Really??? There is about 30 people waiting to check in and only two people working... First time at the Paris and quickly becoming the only one...

I would definitely stay here again. My husband wanted to spoil me and take me to a nice hotel in Vegas and this definitely did it. 

When he booked the room over the phone, they had accidentally overbooked the type of room he requested. They said they would note that in the account and give him the room (based on cancellations) or an upgraded room since they had messed up the reservation.

When we got there, the lady that checked us in was quite rude and said, "I can get a manager but they will tell you the same thing". She wouldn't budge and was attempting to put us in a downgraded room. The manager resolved it to the best of his ability and we enjoyed our nice room. 

Bit of advice, if you book a room with a strip view, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday, you can hear night club music until 5am, they hand out ear plugs. That's not advertised at all on their website. We opted for the mountain view and glad we did! 

Hotel was gorgeous, great amenities and attention to detail.

i had a bad experience here for first time. I normally dont tip the dealer every winning hand untill i cash out my winnings . I was playing routtle and after a while i was up a lilttle and i realized the dealer started spinned the ball so fast ,  she didnt give me enough time to decide what to bet, i missed so many good ones, i believed she was trying to kick us away, she also mentioned "you're so lucky at my table".." you're so generous sir ", i knew that she wanted tip so i tipped but my mood was totally off....i dont think they're supposed to do that..i noticed that no1 came to that table to play

Bedbugs, Bedbugs, BEDBUGS!  

Stayed in room #1593 (June 2013) and discovered several bites on my back, torso, and chest the morning after our first night.  Disgusting!!!  I've read on other forums that the hotel consistently denies the existence of said bed bugs by sending a "third party" to inspect the room.  For obvious reasons, the rooms come out "clean."  I have posted several photos of my bites on Paris' Yelp! page.  

The hotel as a whole has it's ups and downs:

Pros:

1.  Conveniently located in the center of the strip.  Our room the second night faced the Bellagio, which made for a nice view of their (Bellagio's) water show.

2. Parking\/hotel\/casino are fairly small, which means less walking from your car to your room.

3. Nice dÃ©cor and ambiance (shops and restaurants).  It feels like the French version of Disneyland.   
  
Cons:

1. Check-in time is 4 pm.  Expect LONG LINES at this time.

2. Your reservation for a smoking\/non-smoking and queen\/king room is merely a "request."  You may get your "request," depending on the availability.  Do not expect stellar service from the front desk.  Prepare to wait or pay extra $$$ for their up-sell of a larger\/nicer room.

3. DIRTY ROOMS!  As I've mentioned above, bed bugs.

4. Uncomfortable beds.  The first room we stayed in (#1593 with double queens) had old, uncomfortable beds.  You could feel the bed springs underneath you!  Did not get much sleep the first evening.

5. I doubt their food is truly Parisian. If you're looking for authentic, look elsewhere. 

In short, I would NOT recommend this hotel to any of my friends or family.  Next time, I'll spend the extra money to stay at the Cosmo or Bellagio.
Came for birthday weekend and the hotel is beautiful! Had a great stay! I actually won money on the slot machines!

Paris is one of the best places to stay while in Vegas.  The rooms are comfy and the suites feature his and her bathrooms!  Crazy.  It's a great place to gamble and earn comps, but the restaurants could be improved upon.  The Cafe is decent, Buffet is standard, Crepe stand is the best and the pool is a lot of fun.  The Eiffel Tower Experience is pretty cool and you can see views of the strip you can't find anywhere else.  Paris is centrally located on the Strip and is worth staying there every time you go to Vegas.

Where else can you visit the Eiffel Tower without having to go all the way to Paris!? Well..Las Vegas. Overall, not a bad hotel to stay at and the prices are pretty decent when compared to other properties on the strip.

Convenient location towards the center of the Strip, giving you pretty easy access to visit the south end (Mandalay Bay, MGM, Etc), right next door to the Bellagio\/Caesars\/Forum shops, and fairly easy access to the north end (Venetian\/TreasureIsland\/Wynn\/Fashion Show Mall). 

Rooms are not that impressive, but offer a good place to sleep, rest, and relax. They are decently outfitted and offer a decent bang for your buck.

The staff are ok. I don't know if I expected the rudeness (considering it's Paris) but it wasn't bad overall.

Considering their room rates and location, not a bad place to stay at!
Great hotel. Stayed here my first time in Vegas for a discounted rate through Total Rewards and you couldn't beat it. Gorgeous room and great room service.

Atmosphere: 3 
-Messy, not organized
-Maze surrounding the casino (Naturally) 
-Loud

Cleanliness: 1
-Old carpet 
-Hotel rooms smelt like chemical (had to air out the room through the door) 
-Lights, bathroom...etc. are all old 

Price: 3
-You get what you pay for, but its a good price for a hotel on the strip 

Location: 4 
-On the strip, great location.

Checkin: 3
-Easy
-Through an automated machine

Notes:
-Room key cards are awful, had to go to the front desk to get it reprogrammed (other guests as well) 
-Wifi slow 
-Elevators old and small

I love this hotel. I felt like walking through a small city after having a pleasant dinner at Gordon Ramsay Steak. 

The entire walk is short-lived however and it connects right to Bally's casino. I did not stay here so my rating is solely based on the casino, indoor decor and stores.
