The Casino was very clean and the machines were current. The wait staff were top notch as they were always willing to help and were very nice.

(This review is only for the chapel and wedding services provided at the hotel.)

My wife and I were married there Monday afternoon 1\/5\/15.  We had family flying in from both coasts for our event.  Our ceremony was by far the best part of our trip.  Our wedding coordinator Elisabeth, was courteous and very professional.  Mike, the pastor who married us was very personable and simply a pleasure to be around.  He made both my wife and I feel at ease and very comfortable.  Our ceremony went off without any issues.  I must say I am thrilled with our photographer Tina! She took over two hundred photos with us and our wedding party and we were thrilled with almost all of them.  Most chapels in Vegas are cheesy, but not this one!  This entire experience has been money well spent and the happiest moment of our lives was exactly what we wanted it to be.  Our expectations were exceeded and we would highly recommend this venue!

The location is nice and the line to check in shorter than others I've experienced on the strip.  The cabled internet is fairly fast but $14 a night.  Interesting choices for restaurants inside this hotel and the whole fake french thing is a trip.

I stay the last week of July 2015 and my room was dirty half the time I was there. I talk to the front desk supervisor on the Thursday before we left and said he would take of the problem. the next as I was checking out I had another problem in my room and it took one hour before they came to my room. My union has use this hotel many time. I hope they think twice before coming back in two years. They tell you what you want to here. I think  people should do some research before getting a room at this resort. It would be nice to here from the hotel manager to hear what he has to say.

I went to Vegas with my friends to celebrate our birthdays in early September. It was my first and last time there. Although I had an AMAZING time with my friends and loved the shows, the entire experience had a big damper put on it when someone stole my things from our room. They took my prescription glasses, sunglasses and bracelets. They had the nerve to put someone else's  sunglasses where my prescription glasses were on the bedside table. It has taken this long for Paris Hotel\/ Caesar's to tell me that they will not be paying me anything for the claim as the employees that entered the room denied any wrong doing. So, if you feel the urge to go to Vegas, don't stay at the Paris Hotel and I encourage you to lock up anything important to you, including your prescription glasses.

Love, Love, Loved this place!! We booked our trip through travelocity, and originally it was for 8 days @Mandalay. After 3 days at Mandalay, we called travelocity because we were miserable (see that seperate, long, review), and (travelocity has a "happiness guarantee"  for the trips they book for you), and we begged to be released from Mandalay hell. After explaining to them that we were not happy due to their poor customer service, lack of housekeeping, etc, they agreed to re-home us at the Paris. We were SO happy!!! We re-packed our things, ran down to Burger Bar (the best thing in Mandalay) grabbed our take out order and jumped in a cab and we were OFF! Paris was wonderful. Pretty, romantic, GREAT customer service. Concierge was always polite and very helpful. Housekeeping was on it. There were soft, clean towels there everyday, beds made, glasses replenished. The AC was COLD!! Great restaurants as well- Mon Ami Gabi (see review), Le Creperie, Le Boulangerie, etc. We had an amazing strip view. We could see the pool, eiffel tower, and Bellagio fountain show from our room on the 9th floor. The room was decorated like a Parisian bed and breakfast. Very quaint and cozy. We did not have a jacuzzi in our room, but the regular tub and the standing shower sufficed. Would Def stay here again. The pool area was AWESOME! The pool is HUGE. There is never anyone on top of you, and there really werent many little kids there which was right up my alley. You can go to the pool at ANYTIME from 8am-8pm (if people are in the pool past 6, they dont kick you out till 8)... You can get a chair at the pool ANYTIME as well. They are also 2 outdoor jacuzzis, and lockers for rent for $5 should you need them. You can have as many towels as you want for the pool. They dont need to see your room key everytime, and the are not militant with the blowing whistles or stingy with towels like other hotels. (In retrospect, I probably couldve gotten my friends in to use the pool, but they were too busy gambling. Lol.) It had a very laid back feel to it. They served drinks to you IN THE POOL, and you could pay there or charge them to the room. Great souvenir cups\/sports bottles as well. They also have a cafe by the pool for breakfast\/lunch, or you can get a menu and have the food\/drinks delivered to your chair. Paris is located RIGHT on the strip. You can walk to a few nearby hotels such as Planet Hollywood, the Miracle Mile shops, and the Bellagio. The monorail stop is in Ballys and you can walk through Ballys right into Paris. Along the way, you will see some live music in Ballys, as well as the dueling pianos at Napoleans. Its free to get in, but get there early for a seat as well. Nice but not as crazy fun as pianos at Harrahs. Well worth the trip over there. Boulangerie had great French bread, sandwiches, and gelato. (coffee gelato was the BEST!) The Paris buffet was not good at all. Went there last year and waited way too long and paid waay too much and there wasnt anything good in there to eat. Skip that and go across the way to Le Creperie. Get an awesome crepe for $8 and it will fill you.Loved that place.

For the price, I have nothing to complain.

Room is okay, you can sleep there with no problem. The one we got probably was on a club side or something.. we could hear club music until 3AM, which is not so good.

Their buffet was nice. I got the Groupon, so it was a good value.

The casino is old looking. I can imagine it was one of the coolest casino on the strip at one time.

I think I'll always have good memories of Paris which is why I'm generous with the rating. Our room was decently sized. It had a strip\/tower view and we were on one of the higher floors so it was really nice. The bathroom was really small though, but who goes to vegas to complain about a bathroom? The hotel itself is always crowded, and the line for the buffet can get ridiculous.

One of my main things to do when I went to Vegas was relax at the beautiful pool. One of the reasons I choose The Paris Hotel was for the pool. I was so disappointed......1. It looked like there was a frat party moments before. Beer bottles and cups littered the entire area. Yes people should be responsible and throw there own trash away but isn't that why we pay such a ridiculous resort fee to have clean grounds??? There wasn't a clean area around the entire pool. 2. Not only was there cups around the pool but also inside the pool as well at used bandaids, napkins, plastic wrappers and so much hair it stayed wrapped around my ankles. Disgusting!!! 3. The chairs were strait out of Motel 6, plastic, white and blue stripped that probably hadn't been cleaned in years dirty and sticky on all the sides. The Paris Hotel should be ashamed of themselves!! Never will I stay there ever again!! And if you are thinking about it and wanting a nice relaxing time by the pool stay somewhere else. The Flamingo was 10 times better than the Paris will ever be.

I left my heart in Paris.. I had reserved a room with two queens and a view. Upon arriving, close to midnight on a weekday I was informed they did not have my room :( Luckily, Casey was able to get us a room with two beds although it did not have a view. We were staying for 5 days, but had to fly out to Utah on the second day. Upon returning, Jenny at the front was able to switch us to a room on a higher floor with an awesome view of the fountains and the Eiffel tower!! I loved it! The room itself was clean and beds were comfortable. I love, love, love the location!!! It was perfect. The restaurants are great as well! It does get very crowded I noticed (even on a Monday) it was packed!!! All in all it was a great stay and we will be returning next month!!

2014 YELP 365 CHALLENGE - 87\/365


I'm glad Bally's is connected to Paris because that was the only thing good about our stay at Bally's to be honest. We ate at a restaurant at Paris which was a good experience and the casino wasn't too packed. We enjoyed gambling there. Restrooms were clean too!

I am giving Paris a 1 star because staffs here are outright rude from the porter to the front desk. We visited Vegas in August 2015 and we picked Paris for all the wrong reasons, I guess. Granted, this is our very first time here, we will definitely never return.

The porter asked if I had a room number yet and I said no, they haven't emailed me back. Mind you, I am a well educated Asian woman. The porter, when explaining to me the check in procedures, SPELLED his answers out to me as if I was illiterate. W-I-L-L WILL, THEY WILL CALL YOU WHEN THEY ARE AVAILABLE! We did online check in from the website with the hope to get in early: they clearly have the options to check in as early as  7:00 a.m. so we willingly paid $20 to get in at 9:30a.m. When we arrived the front desk lady told us they never have any room ready by 10 a.m. so I should "try my luck later". So asking if we want to check in as early as 7 or 8 is just false advertisement. 

I was extremely upset with Paris staffs behavior and service. I assume they are big enough of a hotel they do not mind upsetting a bunch of customers. But spare yourself the nasty, white privilege attitude and chose another hotel! I am in for a holiday, a real good time, not this.

Pros: 
-Mini fridge was empty, allowing us to store our leftovers. 
-Bed was comfortable
-Online check in and checkout offered
-Friendly dealers

Cons:
-No bathroom fan
-View outside our window was of the top of another building, nothing special. (We had a 2 queen red luxury room)
-Resort fee is really high considering I used none of the services it includes

Stayed here 2 nights with a buddy. I had stayed at Caesars all prior times in Vegas. This is not Caesars. It's a decent hotel though. No major complaints. I won some money here at the tables playing blackjack.

Pool was nice, spacious , not like other hotels where the chairs are on top of eachother. Buffet lines were LONG.... food was ok, not extraordinary. Location is perfect, short walk to Ceasars, planet hollywood and other great hotels, casinos. We rented the cabana and for 200.00 (mid-week price) We got a nice snack basket, sunscreen, unlimited sodas, waters and juices, 2 rafts, TV, music, waitress and those misters that kept us cool the whole day! I would recommend this hotel and would definately stay here again

My Husband and I had a great stay at Paris! When we arrived, our room we reserved was booked so the front desk put us in a brand new suite for the night which was spectacular!   Our regular room was also very nice, everything was new and updated. We did not hear any construction noise nor did we have problems with hot water. The only issue was that yes, if you have a pool view room you will hear the music from Chateau Night Club, but it's only on Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday. Bring earplugs and you should be able to sleep fine. You're staying on the strip in Las Vegas so this kind of noise is expected. We didn't have any problems with hotel staff, everyone was friendly and helpful. Treat others with respect and you will be treated that way in return. Only rude encounter we had was with a bouncer in the Chateau Nightclub. Overall it was an enjoyable stay.

Very nice place to stay in LV. We have been there two times now. Very classy and colorfull Vegas Theme Hotel on the Strip. Location cannot be topped! 

The walking distance between the garage and the front desk eg elevators to the rooms is - as usuaÃ¶ in vegas - quite long.

Staff is very friendly and rooms have plenty of space. We had a Suite and a RedRoom with Strip view. Both rooms where just right as expected. 

The makeup and decoration of the hotel is outstanding. I would say that its THE optical highlite on the strip.

The price range is quite high for Las Vegas - for that reason i give one star less.

It would be my favourite place to stay if the price range would decrease by 15-20%.

I called the front desk because there wasn't any hot water in my room, she said you have to turn on the sink, the tub and the shower faucets all at the same time to get hot water!! Haha I told her I knew that!!! SMFH! WTF? Would be negative stars if there was an option!!

Great place, clean place. Last time stay there, bathroom kinda moldy..iu...not a great scenic. Still great place, awesome people. Eat @ their sushi restaurant, its ok food, price little high but u know its turist town...good time

Paris was so much fun, my girlfriend and I stayed for just one night. The view of the tower was beautiful and the theme inside the casino is very cool. The pool was closed during our stay so we'll have to come back for that. The staff is super friendly and they let us check out bags in prior to us checking in our room. The cafes in the casino were nice Vegas days are long and it's nice to have something to keep you going. The room itself was quiet and clean and we had a partial view of the bellagio waterworks. It was a nice size too, but the furniture was a little outdated.

We didn't have a great experience staying at this hotel for Valentine's Day like we had hoped that we would. 

We booked the "Red Room Luxury" in October, but when we came to check in around 2pm the lady informed us that they "didn't have any of those rooms available"....okay awesome, once again reminded of that Seinfeld episode where anyone can TAKE a reservation, but apparently nobody can HOLD the reservation. Seriously, we booked in October!!

My husband informed her that we would then be expecting an upgraded room since it wasn't our fault that they overbooked their rooms. She went back and forth with a manager for about 15 minutes and left us standing there to listen to the one after another person in the check out lines next to us being offered the opportunity to "upgrade" for a nominal fee, so we knew they must have plenty of places to upgrade us to. 

Finally she came back and said we had been upgraded to a room with a view. We asked her, point blank, "but it's still a red room right? Because we want a red room for Valentine's Day, the view is of no importance to us." She told us that it was absolutely a red room. Great. We were told to come back after 4pm to get our keys, so we checked our luggage and went off to do a few hours of exploring.

Fast forward to 4:00, we pick up our keys, go to the room, open it up and the room is....PURPLE AND GREEN. Not a trace of red in the whole thing. We were annoyed beyond control, but we DID control ourselves enough to dial down to the front desk and inform them that they had not given us the correct room. The lady on the phone was extremely rude and argumentative on the phone. She told us it was a red room....wow, that's weird since there was no red in it. She also told us that they were sold out and had nowhere else to put us. My husband was about ready to give up at that point, but that just wasn't going to happen.

We went back down to the front desk and talked to Antonio. He immediately rectified the situation, told us he knew exactly what happened (apparently that room is marked as a red room in the computer even though it isn't red) and he said he could easily move us to the exact room we booked with no problem. He was extremely friendly and helpful and 10 minutes later we were in the exact room we had booked in October. Now I ask you, if it was THAT easy, than why the F did they put us through all of that? Lie to our faces? Argue with us? Seriously? Are you kidding me?! We called a manager to thank him for Antonio's help because everyone else there were total A-holes living up to that whole French attitude even though they were all mostly Hispanic. 

Once we were in the actual room we paid for in October we were mostly pacified, but still irritated at the entire situation. The room was fine, but it wasn't great. There was definitely wear around the edges and you could tell it needs an update.

The casino is neat in there with the sky and everything and we enjoyed eating at Le Cafe (separate review). While I would consider eating there again or visiting the casino again, I will NEVER stay here again, the service was crap except Antonio...he is the only reason they get a 2 star instead of 1.

Shame on you Paris, trying to ruin a couples Valentine's Weekend for NO reason.

I like this place. The Eiffel Tower is nice to look at, and its not too bad inside.

+Le Village buffet is decorated beautifully and the food is great!!! The breakfast buffet was yummy and NOT expensive, which was great.
- Le Provencal you made me sad. Granted, I did order your Angel Hair pomodoro, and I didn't expect much, but COME ON. I've made way better pasta than that and believe it, it wasnt no 13 dollars. But your bread was good.
- Le Cafe, why did you only give me two tiny pieces of my french toast for my combination?! Well fine, at least it was good. I agree with the person who says theyre cheap on bread, they only give out bread to people who buy soup or salad. 
+The rooms were kinda nice. I liked the way they decorated the floors, but...
-COME ON, who are you kidding with that carpeting?!
+But I did enjoy that bathroom you guys gave me.
-UM, grossest thing was that strawberry daquiri my best friend bought me with the eiffel tower, is there like 2000 grams of sugar in that thing or what? and yeah, he carded her and asked her if it was for me. She said no of course, but HA! I got the WHOLE drink mofucka!!!!
+Thank you security officers for being so nonchalant about letting a minor gamble! We lost so tsalll good.

Peace, yo!

You have to pay to gain access to the gym.  That's whack.  You would think that with your paid room you'd have free access to the gym as part of the amenities hey offer.  Nope. 

Paris Las Vegas's Score - 75 Points

My husband and I stayed here for a special occasion and the front desk upgraded us to a room facing the Bellagio Fountains and the Eiffel Tower!  Rooms are gorgeously decorated so chic yet warm.  Very romantic and convenient location.  Wonderful buffet to enjoy especially for dinner, great shows, and piano bar and Eiffel Tower to ride up and preview the strip especially at night!  It's all here and I enjoyed it all!  I will be back! Oh, and did I mention I won $500 on the crap table! woo-hoo!

I stayed here one night with a friend recently during the March Madness festivities. The location on the strip is great and overall is a nice hotel. The walk to the elevator and then to our room was a bit of a trek, but not too bad. I'm not sure what my friend paid or booked, but it was a double bed room and had a nice separate shower\/ bath tub combo. The view was the backside of the strip so not much to look at. 

I had wanted to go to the pool the first day we were there but we had to wait until noon for it to open which was annoying. We waited in the bar outside the elevates and they had $9 mimosa & Bloody Mary specials so not all was lost. We ended up just doing a lap around the pool deck and not staying as the pool was nothing special. 

My biggest complaint was that the helpful old security guard gave me unsolicited directions which ended up having me walk an extra mile through the Bally's construction zone just trying to get back to the strip after he told me about "a great short cut". Never again Wyatt, never again...

This is my fourth stay here. It's about as nice as a motel 6 but cuter and in a great location. I stay here because they allow dogs and I bring them on road trips and sometimes we come to Vegas on the way home. But it is getting run down as others are saying. That's why it's usually cheaper than the others I guess. The first room we walked into smelled like strong dog urine so we walked out and down to lobby for another room. This one smells like curry but we can handle that. But there was small bits of trash on the floor including a stray raisin which can be quite toxic to dogs. And this is a dog room so they should vacuum them thoroughly for the guests. 
The beds are not comfortable at all. They were in the past but I suppose they are old and worn by now. 
Staff has been really friendly so far.
Dog relief area still terrible just a tiny patch of fake grass my dogs don't like to use.

LV is a pit-stop I routinely take on my way to visit family at Lake Powell.  I am not a gambling man so the highlight of my LV trip usually revolves around the shows and the food.  I wouldn't compare Paris to the Cosmo or Aria because the rooms are about half the price.  I am giving Paris 5 stars because of the following reasons:

1. Food - I love Gordon Ramsay Steak because of the quality of the steak and cocktails.  I also love all the little cafes and the crepes.  

2. Staff - All of the staff I interacted with was knowledgable, professional, and courteous.  The receptionist (Fa) made excellent show recommendations and even helped arrange dinner reservations.  The luggage attendant was very courteous.   The pool cocktail waitress (Autumn) was very personable, took time to get to know us, and made excellent drink recommendations.

3. Ambiance - The Eiffel Tower and French Colonial Architecture does add an extra dose of romance to your stay.  The casino floor and shops are arranged like a French village.  We chose the room with a single king-sized bed and our room was not outdated.  The bathroom had travertine tile throughout, a bathtub, and separate shower.    The room had a vintage French couch, a refrigerator, a flat screen TV (although we only used it to checkout), and a coffee table.  My only complaint is that the room didn't have a coffee maker, but I don't think many hotels on the strip have coffee makers these days.

Overall I had a great stay at Paris Hotel.

In a world where you can get free WiFi at the Best Western - or with your Big Mac or your Venti Caramel Machiatto...in a city that is famous for the many things that follow the word 'complimentary'...it is a very odd thing indeed that the Paris does not offer free WiFi to its guests.  To get it you need to either pay a $30 plus per day 'Resort fee' (that admittedly also gets you access to the Spa as well as the also-should-be-free gym) or pay a ridiculous WiFi only access fee.  Did I mention that said fees also only let you use two devices?  Yeah, there's that.  If you and your spouse have smartphones you better have a different plan for your laptop.  This is a particularly crude effort to gouge a few more bucks out of the guests especially in light of the way you are constantly accosted by the half naked women desperately trying to give you free booze every time you cross the casino floor.  

 'No free WiFi' is a deal breaker for me and for that reason I won't be returning for that reason.  However, in the interest of a complete review I'll continue with some further details.  Perhaps the best feature of the Paris is the dÃ©cor - as you can imagine it goes much further than having a giant copy of the Eifel Tower out front.  The entire hotel is done in an opulent French style complete with copies of many famous paintings, and it's done well.  There is an 'avenue' of indoor shops that are set up like a Parisian street.  While the shops themselves are typical Vegas-Tourist setups, the visual effect is pleasing.

The room we were given was an upgrade - apparently the room we reserved wasn't available when we arrived and we got lucky - and we ended up in a semi-suite that was about two and a half to three times the size of a normal room with two separate full baths and a living room\/parlor.  The view was terrible (we were looking at rooftops and the back side of another hotel) but we weren't there for the view and I imagine if that was important to you, you could likely request a room that had a better view.  I read other reviews here that mentioned peeling wallpaper and holes in the walls; I did notice some insignificant peeling in one of the bathrooms (likely due to the presence of the shower) and I saw one hole in a wall in an outer hallway, but overall the hotel seemed to be very clean and maintained.  We did have an initial problem with the television in our room but the staff responded quickly to our report and fixed it right away.

As a final note, the check in\/check out process was atrocious.  There was a HUGE desk for check ins but I never saw more than a third of the windows staffed - even when the lines were literally wrapped back and forth and actually OUT of the reception area into a nearby hallway.  The concierge desk was great for what it's intended for, but don't expect the staff there to be able to answer any questions about the hotel itself; they couldn't even tell me when check out time was or how to get a de-magnetized room key reset.  It turns out (as reported to me by an apparently disgruntled front desk employee?) that the Paris replaced all of its in house concierge staff with a third party crew, and if so that would explain perfectly their otherwise inexplicable inability to talk about the hotel they actually worked in.

So, then, for me:  I've experienced better, and I am unlikely to go back.  If you don't care about waiting forever to check in or out, and you don't care about being gouged for basic services, then the Paris might be for you.  Otherwise, look elsewhere.

When staying at the hotel over this last weekend, we ate at the le cafÃ© and I cut my leg getting out of a booth on the restaurant. I explained to the manager what happened, letting him know there was something sticking out from the area where the two seat  cushions came together.  He advised that he would contact the carpenters to take a look at the booth. I could not show home as the booth was occupied at the time.  The manager asked if I needed medical attention and at the time I said no (it did not seem that bad it the time).   I mentioned this to someone within our party that I've had lunch with us and she also called her late getting out of the booth. 

Today we ate at the same restaurant and noticed that no one had come to fix the booth.  At this time the booth was an occupied so we took a close look, there is a spring\/wire sticking out.

 Totally shocked that the manager didn't seem to do anything to secure the safety of future  patrons of the restaurant from the booth.  I was going to mention it to the manager again as it was the same manager on duty today as was the day before, but he was currently in discussions with the lady who didn't seem very happy and I needed to catch a flight. 

A friend that was in our party mentioned an incident like this had occurred to another friend of hers and that friend had to be tested for AIDS and other blood born  diseases a year.
Had I known this I would have gone to the hotel front desk and pointed out the incident and the lack of any precautions taken by the restaurant management.  But I will be calling them tomorrow to report the incident and let them know that if my leg still sore I will be going to the doctor and submitting a bill to the Paris hotel for payment.

This hotel is getting old... like the rust on the Eiffel Tower. Everything is super-sized and Americanized compared to the real Paris.

- Petite Crepes are replaced by gigantic ones as big as the wheels on my SUV
- Cafe Espresso comes in a 24oz soda paper cup and watered down
- the blue\/gray sky is replace by a very painted blue one
- small French derriÃ¨re walking around on the streets are replace by very big derriÃ¨re (that what happens when people consume super-sized food items)

oui oui. Merci.

Everything was great until i took my morning shower an had hairs everywhere pubic hair etc in so disgusted i almost threw up i had my barefeet on this nasty floor poor housekeeping..supa gross wth 200 dollars a note for dirt shower.wow.oh an the girl at spa so rude i felt so uncomfortable she didn't greet rude ass chick

Mit Abstand das schlechteste Dinerbuffet das ich in Las Vegas je hatte. Teuer, kaum Auswahl, und das Wenige was angeboten war katastrophal schlecht und eklig. Das Personal unfreundlich, inkl. der Toilettenfrau. Nur teuer und nur ekelhaft! never more!

This is for the blackjack dealers. Was refused service on account of my card. At the first table I went at, I said hi, showed my ID, and handed her 100 dollars. She didn't give me chips and told me to leave because she wouldn't accept my card. I was mortified and stunned. I'm a 95' baby, and it's 2017. It's impossible for me to not be at least 21. The next table accepted my cash, which was okay. She took my money. The tables were near empty FYI. One star for the table that turned me away and two for the other table for at least doing her job. .5 stars for the pretty decor though. Won't be back until anything changes and will be warning my friends to avoid this place.
Didn't stay here, but went to the casino bar for a drink and the bartender there makes a mean dirty martini.

This place is outdated the mini frig didn't work the towels are old, the wallpaper has holes, the shower had mold in it.  when I went downstairs to get another room I was given an eye rolled and the same type of room only difference was the frig worked. it just made a loud terrible noise! I'm never staying here again!

I have a lot of nice things to say about this place, starting with the painted blue sky with clouds on the ceiling. It lightens it up a bit, so it's not as dark and drab as a lot of casinos seem to be.

The restaurants in Paris Las Vegas are generally quite good. The rooms are attractive, clean, and fairly spacious. The monster Eiffel Tower drinks last forever.

In general, the vibe here is young and friendly. People are here to have a good time. Definitely one of the better (and yet reasonably-priced) places to stay.

Me and my husband come to vegas 2-3 times a year. We like to stay at different places to see how they are , Paris by FAR has been the WORSE! The rooms are not what they make it seem at all. That "bath tub" is big enough for my 4 year old daughter , good luck fitting in there , keep in mind I'm 5'2 115 pounds and I barely could sit. The customer service is the worse , we called to complain and upgrade and rudely were told "there's no other rooms available ! Terrible hotel! Invest a little more and stay somewhere else! We're stuck here until Sunday because we can't even get our money back to leave, but we will NEVER stay here again, and we'll make sure all our friends and families know how terrible this place is! Management could of at least tried to help us, instead we're rude and hanged up. Trust me when I say , DONT STAY HERE!

I really get my rocks off on theme hotels\/casinos especially when done properly. I absolutely love the architecture, design, mood, uniforms, ambiance etc. of Paris. 

Sadly none of the restaurants are that great. Worse is that they aren't diverse. French, American, or Italian are your choices.

Roomed here over the Christmas holidays. Smack my ass if this is anything like the real Paris-- more like a cheesy Americanized imitation...but still oddly enjoyable and pleasant. 
I had a fantastic room-- upper floor with views of the Bellagio fountains and the Eiffel Tower. Nice clean room, huge bathroom. Room service was quick, with an extensive menu, but the food was only fair. 
Beware the lines for food at the Paris-- they are huge! It is nearly impossible to get into the buffet, one of the best on the strip. I ate breakfast here-- there are endless choices, and the dining setup is really nice. 

Cocktail service was good-- got lots of drinks while playing nickle slots, surprising given this is the Strip. 

The best thing about the Paris= location. It is in the dead center of everything, you can't go wrong staying here if you want to be in the center of the action. 
Message to parents-- don't bring your little kids to Vegas, its not for them!

The best meal I had during my stay was at Mon Ami Gabi, the bistro near the front of the hotel.  Wonderful, simple, delicious food.
This is one of our favorite stops in Las Vegas. Great food, shops and sightseeing. I recommend at least a passing visit.

Love this hotel! We were on the 27th floor in one of the red rooms that have great views of the strip, Eiffel Tower and Bellagio fountain. Room was very clean as well as the bathroom. No issues with noise either. Room service was good, would like to see more French items on the menu, it's a fairly basic menu, salads, sandwiches, hot entrees and breakfast etc. lounge downstairs is so pretty, didn't get a chance to hang out there. Staff has been amazing! Only negative I'd say is the check in process, I totally get it's Vegas and there's going to be a crazy amount of people in line waiting to check in, these hotels need to accommodate that much better, they never have more than 4 people checking people in and there's always room for a lot more employees to help. Seems it's like that at most Strip hotels. We like to stay at a different hotel every time we are here, but I would totally come back to Paris again for sure, maybe upgrade to one of the suites next to check those out.

Our 3rd stay at Paris and our last. The nightly room rate gets you nothing. The Front Desk Clerk told us that even though our room was ready we would have to pay $25 to get in before 4PM. Although....if we paid $40 to upgrade our room they would waive the Early Check In fee.  Wink wink.  We had to schlep our bags all the way outside, down the walk by the Taxi Stand to have the Bell Desk check them. THEN at 4PM we had to wait in the key pick up line, wait 30 minutes in our room for the Bellhop to bring our bags...and to add insult to injury, had to TIP the bellhop for bringing our bags. What a scam.

Of course there is the nightly Resort Fee of $20 added on top of the nightly room rate. The Resort Fee is supposed to get you free wifi, BUT only for one device. Really? My husband and I had to choose whether his phone, my phone, his work laptop or my work laptop could get on the internet each day. Forget our iPad. If we had wanted to get all 5 of our devices on the internet, it would have cost an extra $60 each day.  We finally had to cough up an extra $15 so we could both get some work done on the 3rd day.

This was supposed to be a vacation, not an exercise in annoyances. We decided next time we're going to a hotel that gets all our money up front and actually gives us something for it. It won't be a Caesar's property.

For the price, location and cleanliness, the Paris is a great hotel for anyone.  I found the staff to be very friendly (through bag check in, room service, direction in the hotel, etc...)

I'm not sure what room I stayed in, but the bathroom was large, plenty of counter space to get ready and mirrors everywhere which is always a plus.  There was a king size bed, along with a decent size sitting area.

Not to be a bitch, but I noticed someone mentioned how the hotel has old TVs....  um, WHY ARE YOU WATCHING TV WHEN YOU'RE IN VEGAS?  Who chills in their room in Vegas, no one!!!  If you're looking to chill, Vegas might not be the destination of choice. 

Another thing you can't shake is the LOCATION, so central and overlooks the Bellagio, which I think is better than actually staying in the Bellagio as you can see the building and fountains from afar.  

The pool and hot tubs - I think this might be a secret but I was a huge fan.  It's not as big of a scene (there wasn't a bar) but I mean that didn't prevent me from BYOB.

I'm not a gambler, the the casino part doesn't really interest me.  This might be because I wasn't as tossed, but I feel Paris doesn't have the stigmatism and other hotels in Vegas has (such as Bellagio or Flamingo) which I dig,  

I also remember calling for a late check out, which was easily accommodated, thank you Paris.

My wife and I stopped by Paris casino on our last trip to Vegas to watch Jersey Boys. The casino is pretty nice here. I think the ceiling is painted with clouds so it looks like it's day inside. I've never stayed at the hotel here but I've been through this casino a few times. The last time I came here, my wife and I ate at Gordon Ramsay Steak here at Paris. The casino itself isn't that bad. It has a good layout of slots and table games. We stayed here after the show and played a little bit. The waitresses were really nice and we had good service. They were always checking up on us to see if we needed any drinks.

You can also take a ride up on their eiffel tower, but I've never done that before but it probably is nice at night to see all the Vegas lights on the strip.

Woke up at 4am by next door people talking and we could also hear the music from the nightclub. Very noisy hotel.
They charge you for wifi-access ! You are allowed only one device and have to connect only from the room otherwise they charge.. (around 25 per device per 24h)... Of course they don't tell you that!
Lots of same price range hotels to stay in LV so I will pick another one next time

This is probably one of the worst hotels I have ever stayed at. Our key was not working and instead of working with us to let us into our room they threatened to have us stay out the entire night. Both the front desk as well as the manager were beyond disrespectful and attacked us. The manager proceeded to even tell us to shut up at one point. The service was the furthest from hospitable and was one of the worst experiences in my life. I highly recommend going anywhere other than the Paris Hotel.

The hotel overall is what gets 4 stars from me. The rooms, although nice and quaint, are what you're supposed to get (the standard bed, TV, and phone). Nothing less, nothing more.

It is right on the strip, so if you want to go up and down the strip to enjoy Vegas, then this is a good place to stay. The "Little France" thing going on is pretty cool (especially when you're taking someone special around, but it's Vegas. You shouldn't. =P ), and the overhead clear skies ceiling is great to look at when you're intoxicated. The casino floor is very clean and the shops serve their primary purpose. The swimming pool, however is almost always crowded. Not that I have a problem with that, but waiting around to get in the pool almost gave me a Wesley Snipes tan. No joke.

NOTE: A problem I have with certain hotels all over the states is that they do not provide free wireless internet. They charge you a ridiculous fee per day to use it (something in excess of 10 dollars). Luckily some casinos in Vegas have it, this one (when I went last summer) sadly did not.

Due to high winds in Chicago, our flight dumped us into Las Vegas pretty late and consequently The Paris "upgraded" us to a suite for the night. The front desk clerk who checked us in was very nice, made sure when we switched rooms we would have a renovated one, and good thing. The suite was filthy. The chair looked like many greasy haired people had rubbed all over it, the marble table had multiple - I mean ALL OVER - drink ring marks, and some sticky substances on it, the bidet (yes, there was a bidet in the suite) had an old cup lid behind it, and the TV was small and all the way across the room, so watching in bed was impossible. 
After re-packing, going back downstairs, waiting in line, and a mix up at the front desk (the surly front desk staff couldn't find the name under which the room was reserved, even though we had checked in already), we got back up to the renovated room (after wasting a good 45 minutes of our day), on the back side of the hotel. A 50\/50 view: lots of parking lot but also some beautiful mountains (and I can only imagine much quieter than a front of hotel room). 
The pool is less than relaxing with a very loud DJ playing 80's\/early 90s' "mash-ups" (if that's what you can call them) and I saw a little kid puke on the steps while his drunk mom tried to catch it in her margarita cup. Classy.
The hotel\/casino area is always crowded and noisy. Maybe that's just Vegas, but they bill this place as "Everything Is Sexier In Paris." Guess that doesn't include the oldies in sweat pants and fanny packs. The signs all have "Le" in them. "Le Car Rental?" Give me a break. Didn't see any of the aforementioned mimes, though, thank God.
Upon checking out, the much surlier front desk staff said we were being charged $700 bucks to the credit card on file. We pre-paid through an online booking service. Um, excuse me? She disappeared to the back for about five minutes, came back out, didn't say word one to us, then handed us the bill for $15\/day of internet service (biggest rip-off in Vegas, and that's saying a LOT), and continued to look down, typing away. After we had stood there for a minute, she finally said "oh, you're all set." and that was that. No: "sorry for the mix up," no "thank you for staying here," no "come again soon!" I've gotten better service at Howard Johnsons in middle o' nowhere Illinois, and didn't pay nearly as much for it.
The two stars are for the renovated room and the nice front desk guy at the beginning of our visit. The location is premium for the strip, but so is the location at Ballys, Bills, and Planet Hollywood, none of which I stayed at but all had nicer casinos.

Edited to add: oh, yeah, no one ever checked room keys in this place, and the area outside the elevators was one of the busiest in the whole hotel\/casino.

Just got back from spending 2 days at the hotel. It was very impressive with the decor and cleanliness. The beverage servers and casino staff were very polite and engaging. I haven't been to a better customer service venue such as this.

The downside is the over serving of obnoxious drunks who become rude and boisterous as though common courtesy doesn't pertain to them. Forget signing up for the player's cards because the points you supposedly accrue are not worth it. It is one of the stingiest experiences we've had.

Fairly recently it looks as though Vegas in general has opted to withdraw the welcome mat for families. The sidewalks are filled with college age or a bit older youths who come to booze it up and score some drugs. Peddlers were handing out cards for strip clubs which is fairly tacky if you're walking along with your wife and\/or kids.

Just one guy's opinion. If you want to let loose, party, and be in a fantasy setting then this is the place for you. Back to Lake Tahoe for me!

Unlike other yelpers found, our room and 11th floor hallway  was not outdated in the least.  I, admittedly, tipped the front desk in the hopes of getting the best room available and we ended up with a great view of the pool, tower and Bellagio fountains.  Double king room was spacious and amenities were great.  Housekeeping failed to get to our room one day --- but, were quick to rectify the problem when we notified them.  The location is fantastic with easy, access Bally's and other casinos around it.  It is smaller than many of the other casinos.  I like that.  By the fifth day, I felt I knew almost everyone at the tables, and service was consistently fun, friendly and helpful.

i didnt stay in the Hotel, but as i was walking around, i kicked it in the casinos smoking lounge and watched the horse races. it was interesting how nice the staff is, i wasnt gambling and they didnt kick me out. even brought me a coke. 

I think i want to stay here next time i visit vegas!

This is not the fancisest place on the strip, but the rooms are comfy, the bathrooms large, and the price is almost always right. Join Total Rewards and they always will give good deals on this property. I've never had a problem here and always been very happy with my stay.

It's a good place for kids, the location is perfect, and the pool is great (the Eiffel Tower looms over it).

I love the casino. The theme is spot on Parisian. Stay away from the restaurants though - we were disappointed with most of them. If you do go to the buffett, hit the crepes first... but trust me, the line is not worth it.

I left my purse containing my ID, $$, and Credit Card on the table while enjoying french toast at 4AM.

I called lost and found in the AM and everything was there. ALL $200!!! 

I love this hotel, I love this staff and I am writing a fully detailed report as soon as I have the time. All in all a safe, fun, and clean hotel. 

C'est La Vie

Paris is a fun and refreshing hotel.  It is beautiful unlike the MGM green monster and the staff are friendly.

I much prefer Caesars group of hotels than the MGM monopoly...which includes Circus Circus.

Great food.  Charming.  A Vegas value!

We showed up at 8:30PM. They sold the room we had prepaid for (king\/non-smoking) so they said we could have a a double or we could pay $40 extra to upgrade to a king in a bigger room. So, if we wanted to sleep in the same bed, we had to pay $40 extra rather than them upgrading it for free since they sold our room....that we prepaid for. The upgrade was supposed to be a great view of the Bellagio and Eiffle tower. We got an awesome view of the parking lot. Then, the "resort fee" of $20 a day that gets tacked on to the total....it includes one visit to the workout room per day for two people and wireless connection for only ONE device. What?!? Then, we get to our room after dinned, turn on the TV, and it's broken. All we get us CNN. That's it. I called the front desk to talk to someone about it this morning and, while I'm explaining all of this to her, I get, "So, what is your point?" Seriously?!?!! That is customer service at Paris Paris. We will never be back. Ever.

Worst experience of my life. On the second night my boyfriend and I moved all the pillows from the second bed over for extra comfort and passed out. When I woke up I looked down at my pillow and saw a light tan color and figured it was my makeup I grabbed one of the other pillows and went back to sleep. After taking a shower I stopped and looked closer and realised it looked a bit darker than my makeup. I sniffed it and found that it was some other persons feces. I immediately escalated to hotel management got a case started and they switched rooms for us. 

First thing we did is check the new room for feces.  Luckily we couldn't find any. Although  we did find a bloody qtip. The next morning around 9 am we were awoken to the sounds of construction in all rooms around us. So much banging this consisted all day disrupting our sleep even more. In addition Paris now pumps a scent into their hotel that made me 100% loose my voice for almost 2 weeks. So come bill time you think they would have atleast comped the shittiest  (literally) of the days. Nope we got a nice bill for 3 thousand dollars. I have attempted to call on the case and yet to be contacted back.

This is the worst place I have ever stayed and I'm sure it can't be topped. Avoid it like the plague, especially if you have an autoimmune disease.

First time staying here and overall it was a good experience! Check in was super fast, lots of places to eat, sweet pool, Chateau night club is gorgeous and the rooms were average at best. Location on the strip is the reason to stay here and if the price is right I'll definitely be back.

I checked in to my room before I even left my house. The Paris offers online check in and will send an email when your room is ready. You can let them know what time you'll be in and they'll let you into your room early if it's ready. Early entry is not always guaranteed.  You just need to stop by the front desk and pick up your key.  It was the fastest check in I've ever experienced and it's the best thing about staying here.
The actual room is not impressive. It's basic and verges on old. There's a giant armoire in the middle of the room and a TV to the far left. If you have a room with two queen beds then one of you isn't going to see the TV which is weird and crazy.  Upgrade to the red rooms.
There are plenty of places to eat, I've eaten at sugar factory which is now closed and renamed Hexx and I'm told it's still the best place to eat There are coffee shops, buffets and even a Chinese place! Gordon Ramsey steak is also here and I l o v e d the food there (see my review).

I've also been to Chateau and the club is gorgeous (see my review!!) So definitely come here if you have the chance. 

I'll for sure be back but hopefully the rooms get updated soon.

Great Location right in the area of all the action within walking distance of everything. Great Restaurant choices. And the gaming area is great. I don't remember seeing a sports book their. I think you have to use Balleys sports book.

This place is much better than the phoney looking Venetian. The art designers here really did a top notch job. From the lighting to the perpetual twilight, if you like big themed casinos, this is your place.

My only beef is that everything's way too pricey here. 7$ for a drink is pushing it.

I haven't been back here to stay in more than 6 years.  This time it was very crowded.  I couldn't believe all the people that were in town during this time.  With all the hotel deals they were offering I thought it was going to be slow.  

Like I said, it's been a while since we've been here and the hotel is starting to show it's age.  They need to update the casino a little more.  The food is decent, but $15 minimum bets at blackjack and roulette on a weekday?  That's still kind of high.  I get it, it's the strip.  I think I'll move back to downtown and enjoy the low limit tables and being able to walk from casino to casino without having people stop in front of me to take a picture of the "sky" ceiling.

I will forever hate, hate, HATE this hotel. I got a yelp account just to give this hotel a bad review. I lost some very sentimentally valuable items in one of their rooms. NO ONE in the entire hotel seemed to care. Some of the worst customer service I've ever experienced at ANY establishment. My family and I stayed in this hotel for the first night of our vacation and then switched to Mandalay Bay for the remainder of our trip. So, when I realized I had forgotten my items in the hotel room, I was still in the area and returned for them the night after we'd checked out. When I first came back to retrieve my items, I thought it would be no problem. It hadn't even been 24 hours since I'd checked out of the hotel room. First, I was sent to the lost and found. They told me that no items had been found in our hotel room and that they couldn't thoroughly search the room until the guests who were currently checked into that room had checked out. This made no sense to me considering that I knew for a fact that one of the items I had lost, a bracelet, had been left on the bathroom counter and the other item had been left on the bed. So I didn't understand why they hadn't been picked up when they cleaned the room between guests. We continued asking around the hotel for more advice on how I could get my items before I left town for home and trying to figure out HOW it was possible that they cleaned the room and none of my items were small (they weren't particularly small and should've been very easy to see.) We went to the concierge desk, they sent us back to lost and found, lost and found sent us to security, security sent us to the concierge desk. Finally, we asked to speak to a manager. I was hysterical at this point. Bawling my eyes out in the middle of the hotel lobby. 
We explained the situation to the manager. I'm standing there hysterical all the while. He was completely unsympathetic and seemed annoyed to be dealing with the situation. We wanted to know how it was possible that my items weren't found. The only explanation that seemed logical was that the cleaning service had taken or thrown away my things. After speaking to what felt like half of the hotel staff, none of whom seemed to care at all about the situation, I was exhausted and resigned to leaving my name and number so that, when the guests who were then checked in to our old room had checked out and the hotel staff "thoroughly searched" the hotel room (supposedly,) the hotel could contact me to tell me if they found my things or not. At this point, I basically already knew that my items were gone. It seems like this might be a regular occurrence at this hotel. 
This is not the first time I've left a valuable item in a hotel room by mistake. However, this is the first time that I've had any difficulty getting them back. I lost something at a hotel in Hawaii once and the hotel contacted us and shipped it back to me free of charge. Any business that cared about their customers at all would have done the same. It's been three months since my stay at the Paris hotel and every time I think about it, I still get so upset. I can't believe the way I was treated and the way that my things were treated. By far, the worst hotel experience of my life.

The WiFi was horrible too. The Paris is a horrible, horrible place. Do not stay here. And if you do, make sure you don't let any of your valuables out of your sight.

First let me say I am a diamond player and that I never have to pay for my rooms so I cant give a review as far as if it is a good value to stay here but I can say that as far as everything else is concerned I love the Paris hotel. I visit Vegas about 3 times a year and this is my favorite out of the Caesars properties.
The rooms are clean and some I have stayed in have been really luxurious  some obviously need to be updated but for me the room is just place to crash between gambling and eating at all the great restaurants. I love how easy it is to navigate from the rooms to the casino and the layout is easy to pick up pretty quick. Try navigating the Venetian...I think my cousin is still lost in one of the hallways there!
The restaurants here are great. Mon ami gabi. sugar factory are great for breakfast, gorden Ramsey Steak, and the Eiffel Tower are awesome for dinner. The pizza place in hallway is great for late night snack.
My daughter had her wedding here and it was fabulous. (Don't go to the hair salon but that's a different review)
Location on strip is great for me because I play at all the Caesars properties and they are all right there next door to Paris. You should book a room here and put up your clothes and go out and experience the city of sin and not worry about how old the tv is in your room!!

I was expecting to be disappointed, but I actually enjoyed staying here quite a bit. The theme of the hotel was a lot of fun and the location was good. I had a lot of fun at the hotel and would definitely stay here again.

Keep in mind that if you get  strip view room you'll have a great view of the Eiffel Tower, but you won't be able to see the Bellagio fountains very well because of it. 

You will walk A LOT if you go here as it doesn't have convenient access to the monorail (it's a long a$$ walk next door in Bally's) and everything seems like a 20 min walk. I definitely don't recommend it if you are going to a conference at the convention center. 

TIP: DO NOT get the meal plan when you make your reservation - the food sucks and is not convenient - HUGE crowds and college cafeteria taste is sure to disappoint everyone. There's no refunds 72 hours in advance either, so once you discover you don't want it you are SOL. 

I went in the winter so I didn't use the pool, but it was small and simple by Vegas standards. I also thought the casino was below average, but I'm not a gambler so I'm just basing this on appearance compared to those at Mandalay Bay, MGM, Luxor, Venetian, Bellagio, etc...

Prime location, foul, outdated pool area. 

5 stars - Location. If you have a concert a Planet Hollywood, you could easily walk. If you have dinner or a show at Caesar's or the Bellagio, you could also walk. Go around the corner to CVS for bottled water and $5 yogurt if you want to save on yogurt and water at the hotel. 

4 stars - Renovated burgundy room is lovely. The lighting is just OK. Bathroom is a little dark for makeup application. The room lets in light in the morning so bring your night mask. Also, bring your ear plugs. On the 23rd floor facing the Bellagio, I could still hear the music blaring until 2AM and beyond. The Bellagio fountains make a startling "boom" each time they spout. You'll hear it! You DO get a coffee maker and a fridge in the burgundy room. You DO get a safe, an alarm, and a luggage rack. You do NOT get a robe, bottled water, or snacks. 

1 star - The pool area was as bad - if not worse - than described in other posts. I witnessed leather-skinned, 60+ year old women busting out of their bikinis who were puffing away on their cigarettes along the edges of the pool. The men here have nothing on the women. The greased back toupees on the frail frames were even more noticeable when wearing socks with black work shoes. And please, who smokes a cigar poolside? That's just rude. This was like an SNL skit. A thin, oily film coated the top of the cloudy water and people shuffled back and forth from the broken, wobbly beach chairs to the smelly, dated pool. Guests were classless and did not bother to move their beach towels to the bins once they were done using them. If you want a nice pool, DO NOT STAY HERE. 

4 stars - Service is quite good. My room was cleaned on time, as expected. From check in, to the concierge, to business services... everyone was friendly and knowledgeable. I'm dropping one star for the awkward reservation process. Once I reserved a room, I went through a strange series of phone transfers with people who were trying to upsell me on getting a tour of the property for a future hotel credit. It was bizarre.

3 stars - The salon is worth mentioning. The salon felt a little dated. The salon could have been located in Tuna Fish, Idaho. I can't remember a single detail that made it feel french. There was nothing posh about the salon. I went for makeup and a blow-out. While Cindy was a nice person, I felt like the salon could have been much more spectacular. She had a great selection of makeup and hair products, but the general feel of the salon was just.... basic. Though she did a great job on my hair and makeup, I left feeling like I had spent a lot of money of an experience that wasn't that special. 5 stars for Cindy and 3 stars for the salon itself. 

Tip: For those of you who use "Rent the Runway", you can return your rented items via UPS at the hotel business center located between Ballys and Paris. Expect to pay a shipping and handling fees, according to weight. My sister and I paid almost $25 to mail our dresses back to RTR. You should also expect to fill out some paperwork.
Great night ambience. Dancers, a band, slot machines and a bar and food all in the same area. Pretty cool and lively. Definitely could feel a little more like Paris though.

I just spent a weekend here at the Paris hotel and casino. I've stayed here in Las Vegas before in many different hotels and this is by far the WORST one. I mean I am talking about absolutely horrible service. The staff here is extremely rude with no customer service skills. I had called down stairs at 2 am to have a remote control delivered up to my room because it was missing one. The housekeeping staff failed to deliver one, instead, they decided to barge into my room at 6:00 AM TO GIVE ME MY REMOTE. WHAT THE ****! My mother & her friend were also staying here on the same floor a door down. Housekeeping had managed to clean my room but had not cleaned my mothers room for a full day. When my mother called down stairs for some service the housekeeping maids arrived at their room with complete attitude asking what they wanted done. FOR STARTERS... THE WHOLE ROOM WHAT ELSE?! Ridiculous! 
IT GETS WORSE! 
ONE hour later.. five security guards come knocking at my mothers friends room and demand her to leave instantly, because the maid reported that she had thrown something at her. CRAZY!!! After completely badgering my mothers friend.. She packed up her belongings and was forced to leave at 1 am in the morning. She was banned from the hotel. She was not even allowed to explain to the security department that NOTHING like that happened and the maid was probably only pissed off because they had complained to the house keeping department. My mother and her friend then left and stayed at a different hotel for the night. Worst hotel, horrible service, and rude employees. NEVER STAY HERE EVER.

We went to the holiday Champagne buffet. $37 per person but well worth it with endless champagne :)

Um other than that the casino was nice but small, the shops were nice.

I love the rooms here! Actually, I really like the bathroom in the rooms here! So pink and so vintage. lol. 

I got a little lost trying to find my way inside the hotel. It's modeled to look like a string of shops along a street with the casino tables all around the windy roads. Nonetheless Paris is right on the strip and the 3 foot margarita that I picked up did me well :). The check in staff is great. My room key got demagnitized at 3am and the woman helping me just laughed and made sure my next one worked. She even sent someone up with me to make sure my door opened. In a place where drunk people wander and make pointless conversations with the staff I was VERY grateful to have her even want to help me out! 

I really loved the room. It's one of those rooms that I would be content with spending my whole trip in being romantic with the BF. In this instance we spent 3 hours drunk inside while he showed me how much he loved me by taking out the hairpins I had in my hair from my updo (I was a bridesmaid in a wedding while we were there). 

The tables aren't so bad either... I won 20! haha.
Their spa is terrible,  they washed my phone and didn't even answer my claim. The phone is not working and i am an unhappy customer.

FURIOUS with our current stay and experience. Came here to celebrate our 20 year anniversary and our whole stay is completely ruined because of this hotel and their terrible customer service! After checking on on the first night here my wife found several (5-6) prominent BLOOD STAINS on the sheet. Blood was not faded, clearly the sheets were never changed. HUGE HEALTH CODE VIOLATION AND LIABILITY, and not to mention completely gross! Naturally my wife was very distressed and concerned for her health, it's unfathomable that any place would have something like this happen, let alone a hotel like this. Normally would have moved out to a different hotel immediately, but it was the middle of the night and I had a business conference at the same hotel the following day so switching hotels would have been a huge inconvenience, figured I'd let their customer service take over and fix this, Huge mistake!

Alerted the front desk of the situation around 1am. Took at least half an hour for someone to actually respond and come into the room. Manager (Janise) was rightfully appalled and very apologetic, but couldn't locate anyone to actually come and change the sheets so it took 2.5 hours to get clean sheets! When asked to change rooms she said they couldn't do anything. Since it ended up taking until 4am to change the sheets (we didn't get to bed until 4:30am!) they eventually agreed to compensate us for one night, but couldn't move us to a different room.

In the morning asked again to change rooms and was told nothing can be done. Spent a while bouncing back and forth between front desk people. Then when talked to different manager (Faviola Flores) in the afternoon about what more can be done, she was very dismissive, not really apologetic, and didn't feel like the hotel had any responsibility to do anything else outside of filing a risk report. The only genuinely kind and empathetic person was the security guy who took the report (Michael), everyone else just kept brushing us off and acting like it wasn't a big deal. My wife was visibly distressed so eventually after Michael went and talked with the manager (Faviola) she begrudgingly agreed to move us into a different room but refused to do anything else until she got the results of the risk report (which will be completed in 3-5 days after we will no longer be there). She never fully acknowledged how serious this situation was or explained why it happened and what was being done to fix it, just dismissed us to write a report and said she can't comment on anything that happened the night before since she wasn't the one there. When asked to speak with someone else regarding customer service, she said there was no one else superior that we could talk to and she was the one in charge of customer service.

You would think after a HUGE mess up like this a hotel would be bending over backwards trying to do damage control and convince us that they can do better. Instead almost everyone acted like it wasn't a big deal, we got shuffled through the bare minimum protocol, got barely an apology, rude customer service, and were made to feel like, in the end, they were doing us a favor by changing the sheets and moving us to a different room. Unbelievable.

I cannot imagine a more upsetting experience and a worse customer service. Completely ruined our anniversary celebration.

Enjoyed my stay at the Paris. Would I stay there again? No..I go to Vegas all the time, figured I would try out the Paris...  The room had a mildew sort of smell. Complained about the matter and it wasn't resolved unless we downgraded. Enjoyed the pool area and the restaurants.

We just got back a few days ago. This was our first time staying at Paris but not our first visit to their casino. In the past we always loved the casino. Its so nice here. So this time we decided to actually stay in a room here. It was beautiful. The room was very nice and clean. The bed was very comfortable. I love that you have a seperate shower from the tub. But the water pressure sucks. The view was amazing. I have read in other reviews that there is a noise problem at the pool. We were right above the pool and never heard a thing after it closed, about 7-8pm I think. Maybe people were hearing the music for the fountains across the street. But that only lasts a few minutes at a time.
Great places to eat like Mon Ami Gabi. Great eggs benedict unless your gluten free, then try something else. Hexx has amazing steak and eggs for breakfast, I would say the best I ever had. The buffet was a pretty cool set up and the food was pretty good. 
The bar , Gustav's, is slow and weak drinks and expensive. I would avoid it. But if you like those frozen drinks you need to get one from the place out in front of the casino. I think its called Arc, but not certain. They make them strong and if you take your cup back you can get it refilled cheaper. 
I love that Paris is pretty centrally located on the strip. We did so much less walking this time.
We will be back someday.

Beautiful inside and out. The rooms are not impressive, but we didn't spend that much time in it anyways.

The location of the hotel is very centric. It'll only take you about 20-30 minutes to walk down to the Mandalay or up to the Palazzo. The hotel seamlessly connects to the Bally which has a walkway to the Bellagio an Caesars.

The exterior is very impressive, the Eiffel tower, the blue balloon and the arch lend it a somewhat surreal look. The theme is continued inside with three of the tower's legs coming into the casino, a fountain, faux cobblestone paths, and a bridge with red street lights that less to the elevator to go up the tower completing the scene.

There are plenty of amenities: several bars throughout the lobby and casino floors and several restaurants and shops, many on the walkway that leads to Bally.

Check in was quick and easy, the $39 daily resort fee threw us for a loop, but there was nothing to be done about that, so we put that behind us.

We originally had asked for a room with an Eiffel tower view, but after they mentioned that it can get noisy site to its proximity to the street we outed for another room, this one was right behind the arch, which still provided a decent view.

The room was pretty standard: a spacious bathroom with a small tub and small shower, a spacious room with with two queen beds, an armoire with a mini fridge, and coffee maker. I don't know how long the hotel has been operating but I'd say the rooms are starting to show their age. Still, it is all kept very clean.

With so many options on and off the strip it's hard to say I'd stay here again rather than try some place new, but if I had to stay here I'd have no problem.

Funny thing , nobody has change for anything in this place, not the bartenders, not the service people, not the valet stand.  The air conditioner in the room was set at 60 and it was still hot in the room.  The bed sagged...need i say more?  Poor customer service.

Talk about amazing...I not only got a great rate, the the view was just amazing, overlooking the water show from the Bellagio from the 26th floor. I'm amazed that these rooms ate actually more affordable than the basic road motels. My only issue was that I couldn't park my van, with the Yakima carrier in their parking lot, because of the low 7'0" clearance. I had to walk nearly a mile, to their oversized lot. Boo!

I didn't stay here, so for me the best part about the Paris was getting one of those massive margaritas in a bottle shaped like the Eiffel Tower.  There is nothing better than strolling around during the middle of the day sipping a good drink out of a famous building.

The great dilemma, is this resort & casino worth 1 or 2 stars?  I love the location of this hotel and had a room with a view of the bellagio fountains.  Despite those promising facts, I changed hotels after 2 nights.  The casino did nothing for me, nor the mock french streets and restaurants.  I am in my mid 30s and was also on the younger end of those I saw roaming this resort.

The room was kind of blah.....had a nice big bathroom but the normal living area was pretty small.  It is evident that this is an older hotel and casino.   But the main reason for the rating of 1 star.....I have to agree with the other reviewer that commented on the air quality.  Ever time I walked into this resort, I feel like somebody kicked me in the stomach.  The stench of the air was disgusting.  If you look at the painted ceiling in the casino, you might see pollution.  If they were to give air quality ratings to casinos similar to cities, they should tell you to wear a mask and drag and air tank with you into this joint.

And the debate ends with 1 star.  It wasn't a complete disaster but I did end up changing hotels and would not stay here in the future.

I loved staying at Paris. Everything was clean and refreshing. The linens were white and crisp, the bath was clean, everything is bright and airy in the room. The scratch paper pad next to the phone was made from that nice glossy paper, +1 star! Oh yea, my favorite buffet is also in Paris. Weekend brunch is the way to go.

You know what Paris Las Vegas reminds me of? No, not its namesake ...not Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron dancing along the Seine ...not Audrey Hepburn doing a fashion shoot for Fred Astaire. I think of - get this - "Xanadu", that circa-1980 roller disco place that coincidentally a much older Gene Kelly opened so that Olivia Newton-John could wear glitter spandex and sing with her armpits exposed. Yes, it has that same excessive, Disneyesque silliness but without the roller skaters with the fluorescent headbands. Instead, we have a condensed, miniaturized recreation of Paris' landmarks. 

But the irony is that it's a pretty nice hotel if you can get past the expansive casino with the waitresses in their push-up bras and mini-tuxedos. The discounted $100 per night room Jamie W. and I had was clean and showed surprisingly little wear for ten years. The elevators, however, show signs of a few too many revelers' enthusiastic head-banging antics. Note the chipped mirrors at eye-level. But you can still stroll under the faux-blue skies of the faux-boulevards where faux-Parisian bistros, creperies and patisseries. 

The other thing to consider about Paris Las Vegas is its central location along the Strip - just across from those dancing fountains in front of the Bellagio, down the block from all those useless Miracle Mile shops in the Planet Hollywood hotel, and prominent enough to have its own monorail stop. All good reasons to have the definitive Vegas experience here. But now you must excuse me as I join my sister muses and turn into a ray of animated light to get back to Olympus..."Now that I'm here ...Now that you're near in Xanadu ...Now that I'm here ...Now that you're near in Xanadu ...Xanadu!

Word of warning: if you're staying on a Friday or Saturday night and can see the Eiffel Tower, I hope you aren't planning on sleeping.  The screaming and "music" from Drai's sounds like it's right outside of your window, and it goes on all... night... long.  They were very good about moving me (to a smoking room, all they had available, so I had to move again the next day).  The manager said they were supposed to mention this to guests checking in, but they missed me.

Overall, I'm happy... it's a nice, clean, mostly well-maintained property; and everyone I interacted with was very nice.  If you're used to the newer hotels, or the higher-end old places like Bellagio or Venetian, maybe you wouldn't like Paris.  But I don't want to pay $600 a night, and I've been mostly happy with Paris.
no hot water in shower. drain goes wrong on bath. service is anti customer. front desk is rude. never never never live at pairs

Full disclosure: I won two nights at Paris through a silent auction.  I had only stayed there once, years ago, and did not expect it to be in visibly worse shape than back the.  The rooms are small and noisy -- stay on the Eiffel Tower side during the weekend and you'll be up all night with the throbbing dance music from down below until FIVE A.M.  In the morning, service people make a racket in the hallways. In our room, wallpaper was held up with Scotch tape!  Talk about run down. Tiny little tubs, next-to-nothing water pressure and an a\/c system that seems to have two settings (suffocating or freezing) are your main options. Scuff marks all up and down the halls, with literal HOLES in the walls at times.  We got our room for $100 a night in the silent auction and I STILL feel we paid too much.  The staff are generally nice, for sure, and the location is great -- but the "Eiffel Tower Restaurant" sign is half burned-out, and it doesn't take much looking around to see that the Paris has seen many, many better days. With small rooms and tiny bathrooms, pieces of the inside falling apart, and a general threadbare feel, we won't be back.

The location is the best thing about this hotel. You can walk to Planet Hollywood Miracle Mile shops and City Center across the street and other properties. That's about it. Here's what is not good. The room has not been updated and has an old TV and bad mattresses. The staff is not very nice and valet takes a very long time. Best to self park, not that bad of a walk and its through the end of the hotel shops. 

The best restaurant to eat in, which is surprising the least crowded, is the Sweet Factory. They have bfast and lunch items. The food and service there was actually very good. We stayed at Tropicana the third night and found the room and staff to be much nicer there. 

I stayed at Paris when it first opened and it was awesome. Now, the hotel and staff are tired. They need to renovate the entire hotel and motivate their staff. Won't stay at Paris again until they do.

Just checked out this morning!

We were in the red room and it was decent. Basic room, basic layout, basic bed, basic bathroom. Everything was typical hotel room. 

Pros: easy walk from check in to elevators. Close places to bring food back to room.

Cons: weak shower pressure. Bad tv reception. 

I guess after that horrible room at the MGM I was so glad to have a bigger room, and a door on my bathroom. 

Would not mind staying here again.

Great room. Our room was on the corner, over looking the fountains at the Bellageo.. The bathroom was huge. The room was spotless and the hotel is itself was very clean. As you walk through the hallways, you begin to think you could actually be in France. 

 The casino was like many others in the area. I didn't win on this trip, so they are all the same at this point..ha!

I'll start out by saying we have stayed here twice in the past.    This time we were here on a convention from 10\/2 - 10\/5,  so luckily it didn't cost us a dime. .    

The Bad:
Entrance on the side is bad.  Inside appears much darker than most casino.  Restaurant are limited, with everything french food themed.   The rooms are old and need makeovers.   TV are still the large tube type.  No poker room.   Needed to walk over to their sister\/hotel, Bally's to get poke action,   which only had about 4 table going most nights...... 

The Good:
coffee, at most coffee shops....   & central locale.

We didn't stay here and we didn't gamble, but we had a good time nonetheless. We rode to the top of the Eiffel Tower (which cost about $12 a person). The view turned out to be fantastic. Paris is right in the middle of the Strip, so the Eiffel Tower is a great place to get oriented, and to watch the Bellagio fountains from above. The staff were extremely cute and helpful.

We also wandered around the casino, and found it to be charming and decently quiet (both a rarity in Vegas!). Check it out if you've been to the real Paris--you'll enjoy the knock-off art nouveau features.

We all know Paris Hotel is gorgeous but my recent experience checking will keep me away from now on. I booked a room for Sunday night and my friend booked a room for Monday night. We arrived at 9am and wanted to speak to the reception desk to combine our reservations so we wouldn't have to switch rooms the next day. We were turned away at 9am and told we couldn't even talk to someone until 2pm. I wasn't looking to check in early, I only wanted to speak to a reception desk person. I come to Vegas every few months and have never felt so unwelcome. I'm now back at 2pm to check in and combine the reservations and have been met with a line wrapped around the lobby twice. The check in experience is so horrendous that I will definitely pay more to stay elsewhere. But I will be back for the crepes.

I'm just starting to realize that I've turned into a bit of a hotel snob.  Since I travel a lot and am always in a hotel, I can be overcritical of hotels....so proceed with caution! :)

Upon entering Paris hotel, I was honestly pretty impressed.  The chandeliers in the lobby\/check in area are absolutely amazing....I wish I could steal them & put them in my loft.  The Eiffel Tower inside of the hotel is pretty neat.  The fact that it looks like day time ALL of the time makes you want to gamble & drink at all hours of the night, morning, whatever.  I found myself sitting at a slot machine at 5 AM drinking a vodka cranberry wondering what the hell was really wrong with that situation! 

Moving on to our room.  We had a room with 2 double beds & a pool side view.
