So so the rooms need a huge face lift and everything seems like it needed to be repainted. Chairs in room were like half broken super strange. They make aoooo much money at least paint some things to get it looking a bit more attractive. Take the big bulky old tv things out of the rooms!

Very disappointed with my stay at the Paris Hotel. 

Maid service failed on many accounts.

Upon arrival, I started unpacking.  I discovered dirty towels in the wardrobe. 

I checked the Honor Bar to see if there was water.  No water, no food, but I did discover a to-go container of moldy food from a previous guest.  I am afraid to guess how long it had been there. 

The room, 2120, had a joining room with a locking door.  The noise from the adjacent room was loud.  I could hear conversations, people using the bathroom, TV, showering, and brushing of teeth.  There was no privacy.   The neighbors were in and out almost all night.  Fortunately, I brought ear plugs.

On day two, I cut my foot with a piece of broken glass on the bathroom floor.   Apparently, a previous guest broke a glass in the bathroom.  Upon inspection, there was shards littered around the bathroom still.  I picked up what I could locate and left a note for room service.

The decor is in need of refresh.  the beds and bedding look like they are 20 years old.   Lobby and restaurants were passable.  The French decor of the main casino floor was the only portion of the hotel that appear to get regular upkeep. 

I won't be staying here again.

I went to Le Cabaret\/ Paris Casino in Vegas with some friends after a Pitbull concert on 03\/19\/16 and continued the fun dancing with the great band that was playing. I backed into a very distinguished cute guy (literally backed into him while dancing) and enjoyed dancing with him cause he felt good and not creepy. Only regret is I did not get his 411. So Matt from Alaska...thank you for the dances!

The hotel is beautiful from the outside, but with such a name I was expecting a little more class and a better interior. Everything looks overused and tired. From the seats, to the carpets, the curtains to the bedding it's not better than an old motel. 
The receptionist appeared as if we disturbed her schedule and didn't tell us anything about where to go, what to do, but she handed us instead a booklet and sent us away. Every employee we met was not welcoming and seemed to not know anything about the hotel. 
Our bedroom wasn't done until 3 in the afternoon, even though we left it around 9am everyday. 
The bathroom and the view were nice and made up for the rest, but for being a hotel on the strip in Las Vegas, I expected a little more. 
You should also know that in Vegas, uber and lyft are in specific designated area, and the one in Paris is the North entrance which looks like a back alley, and the ideal place to be murdered.

This is where my group of friends and I played most of the time in Vegas and we didn't even stay at the hotel. 
The casino is very nice and well layed out. They have SINGLE Deck cards which is great and the best for black jack. The dealers are super nice and really try to help you win, they talk to you and really try to make sure you have a good time.
That's what I look for in a dealer, you don't want someone to just stand there, deal and not talk to you. I feel intimated when they give you the silent treatment.

Wonderful place to play and the waitresses are sweet as well and always make sure you are filled up which doesn't happen in every casino. 

Go play black jack at Paris!

Was very disappointed with this hotel.  The hotel should consider renovation as soon as possible.  Bathroom was disgusting.  Grime and water stain everywhere. Crap seeping out of the toilet bowl.  Stained floor around the toilet bowl.  Shower partition was just disgusting.  Rugs were dirty. Paint  everywhere chipping.  Just overall dirty and disgusting.

While this hotel is amazingly located right in the middle of everything, with an amazing casino and food court, it is in need of room renovation. We paid $25 extra per night for a "view", which included a partially obstructed view of the Bellagio fountains BUT more so a direct line of sight with one of the Bally's towers. While we had an amazing time in Vegas (and enjoyed the casino floor of this hotel and its location on the strip very much!), the room quality was very poor and has not been renovated for 10+ years. Our room looked more like a motel 6, with wallpaper pealing, numbers falling off the outside, and patches in the carpet (not what I would expect from a place with such a high scale casino anchoring its hotel). From someone who stays in Vegas frequently, I would recommend the recently renovated Linq for the same price over this particular Caesars property. If only I could combine the casino quality of the Paris with the room quality of the Linq, then I'd be happy! Long story short... Don't pay for the "view" option on the standard room. I hear the "red" rooms with a view of the Eiffel Tower and pool are an excellent choice but can't speak to those from experience.

Paris is a great choice when staying on The Strip!

It's in the center, so there are tons of choices for fun. Next door are the Miracle Mile Shops & Planet Hollywood, across the street is the new Cosmopolitan, Aria, & the rest of City Center, attached is Bally's & the tram station, and cab rides anywhere else on The Strip (necessary in stilettos!) are short & inexpensive.

The rooms are not overly lavish like some of the newer super hotels, but not bad either. The beds are comfortable (although they're stingy with the amount of pillows!) and the bathrooms are fine.

The pool is cool in the summer, especially with the magnificent view of the Eiffel Tower replica right there!

There's also a good amount of choices when you need some food to soak up the booze and\/or cure a hangover. There's the Mon Ami Gabi restaurant I've been wanting to try but haven't had time, the Paris Buffet which has crepes and ridiculously awesome pretzel bread, Le Burger Brasserie which is a good casual choice, Le Creperie, etc. You can see I've stayed here once or twice. ;)

My favorite part about Paris, however, is THE BEST BLOODY MARY, made by the cutest and nicest bartender in Vegas, Natalia. Generally speaking, I don't even like that kind of drink! But she makes them from scratch, and are ridiculously delicious. She even caters to different spiciness preferences, depending on individual tastes. We experienced her talent on our last visit to Vegas, and this time beelined it right to her bar (the "Central Bar" by the Blackjack tables) as soon as we had a chance. She typically works the earlier shift (we asked!), so it's perfect for when you topple out of bed and need a "hair of the dog that bit you". Be sure to try one next time you're there - you'll be so happy you did!

There is an resort fee $36\/day charged per day when you checked out. It includes cabled internet and gym which I never used. And It is mandatory. Why don't you include that in the accommodation fee if it is mandatory? If you want to use wifi, you have to pay extra $15\/day. 
The room is old and not cleaned very carefully. We have seen the bags left from the pervious guests. Checking-in is super slow at night. Even thought I asked for late check in, I spent about about 30 min waiting in the line.

Like: The closest you can get to Paris, France in the states if you're unable to make it to Europe. Interior is nice including the rooms with a BIG bathroom with tub and shower separated. Sports betting available. Some shopping available plus food options on the ground floor. They gave us some restaurant credit, which we used for room service and for breakfast at their cafe downstairs. I've been up the Eiffel Tower, which is lovely at night to watch the Bellagio water show from up above. On the strip so it's close to everything with a taxi waiting area outside. 

Dislike: The room had a small tube TV (whatever the non flat screen tv is called) AND it was off to the side so it wasn't in line of sight when in bed (which is how most people in their hotel room end up watching TV). Small fridge wasn't that cold of a temperature. Toilet is in line of sight of the mirror on the back of the door, which can be a little weird watching yourself on the toilet haha.

I love this place mainly because of their super tall Eifel Tower Daquiris YUM!  The inside is beautiful.  Weird that it was the middle of the night and I still felt like I was under a blue sky LOL.
Ok so we played the blackjack tables and the dealer Ray -he's lucky!! Little Asian man.  Look for him.

I just got married here in November and it was awesome. There were, of course, some kinks in trying to plan a wedding in a different state, but everything was perfect. We had all the information we needed, like where to steam my wife's wedding gown. The minister was awesome and not at all cheesy. Everyone was very accommodating. If you're going to get married in Vegas, you should definitely shell out a few extra clams and do it right at the Paris.
Made a hotel change this year and upgraded. Room was much quieter and the bed was great. Lots of good places to eat and good Bloody Marys at the pool!

DON'T STAY HERE UNLESS YOU'RE NOCTURNAL - ALL NIGHT MUSIC 

I'm typing this review at 3am by force and not by choice. As much as I would have loved to get a good night's sleep, for the past two nights I've been subjected to booming music from the outdoor night club. I just went down to the front desk to complain and the front desk woman acted like she could care less about my issue. She offered to move me to a different room but with four hours left in my stay there was no point. She offered one day resort fee comp. Are you serious? I know for a fact they've gotten calls about the music to which she agreed and shrugged her shoulders. I asked for a refund on one night's stay and she flat out told me no.

The thing that really upset me was when she said guests are told about the noise when they check in at front desk. So the only way to know you'll have sleepless nights is if you wait an hour in the front desk line? On top of that she couldn't even feign interest when she said, "I'll mention it to the manager". 

I will never spend a penny in this place again. There are plenty of other hotels that value their guests stay.

My review is on the casino as I did not stay at the hotel, I stayed at bally's. The casino itself is beautiful in my opinion and a great site to checkout on the inside and out. I recommend getting a picture of the Eiffel Tower at night. The restaurants inside are very nice and the food is good, however, some are very overpriced; especially the 'le burger' located near Bally's. You'll pay $15 for a burger alone and about $9 for a draught beer. I would avoid that place unless you truly want to pay a lot for burgers. They do have a good place to get bagels and other breakfast quick eats near their pizza place. The casino floor is very clean and waitresses seemed quick. They also have some neat gift shops. Unless you get a view overlooking the tower and bellagio I would recommend staying at Ballys based off the Paris room reviews to save some money.

I was there for 3 days. My stay was good but they wanted me to pay $10 extra a day to have internet, that is disappointing when I paid so much a night to stay there and not to have a free internet. The fridge has sensor so the minute you move something, your bill goes up, it doesn't even say the price on the items! 
Good hotel but it needs some improvements for the prices they have!

For the price I paid for the room on the weekend, it was not worth it. The outside looks nice and spiffy but it lacked in the guest rooms. It was fairly standard and I would have rather stayed at Alladin for that price. The buffet for breakfast was sub-standard. The crepe restaurant across from the buffet was even better. The only part I liked about the hotel was the section of the Rue de Paix where it connects to Ballys with the fountains, it was absolutely beautiful. Does not look like the tacky recreation of Paris but modern luxurious. Now only if they made it to look like Versailles. 

The place is tacky, gaudy, overpriced rooms with standard service. Our room wasn't even made when we came back to it later in the day. A call to housekeeping was answered on the first day but the next day there was no answer at all. I also think the clouded ceiling is way overplayed. Unless it was a cool video changing shifting one =P

Nice size room, long wait to check in though the line was not too long- they seemed under staffed.  We were told we'd have the wifi at no charge because the "resort fee" included wifi.  When we checked out our bill was correct.  After I got home, we received separate bills for that on our credit card.....it took several calls to the hotel & then to "their service" but they did reverse the charges.  My advice check you statement closely after  you trip to this hotel.  did take advantage for their spa special they offered while we there.  I will review that there spa site

This is not my first choice of places to stay, but it was ok, went in the winter season so the pool wasn't open, parking was ok and it is very close to the mall, has some cool shops inside too. The le crepe was my favorite.. close to the strip(on the stripe)so it's right in the middle of Vegas.
Had fun at the roulette table. It's always a good time when your winning!

Located footsteps from the strip, this hotel is the perfect location for anyone looking to be in the center of everything you would want to see and do in Vegas. 

Luckily my friend was offered an upgrade to the Presidential Suite. With a grand seating area, formal dining room, luxurious bedroom with remote controlled hideaway TV, bath with jacuzzi tub, the suite offered all the amenities to ensure a pleasant and relaxing experience during our three night stay in Sin City.

Rooms were spacious and linens were changed out regularly without a hitch.

I've heard the standard rooms were a bit dated with tube TVs and in dire need of a renovation, but if you can land a suite or higher, I think the stay here is well worth it.

This hotel is OK. They definitely make you feel like you are in Paris, France. All the signs are in French. The ground is black cobblestone. I upgraded the room to a "Red" room. It was also OK. Nothing spectacular. King bed, no jacuzzi tub and horrible view. I would not recommend this hotel if you are young, there were a lot of kids at this hotel. I didn't make it up to the Eiffel Tower ride, but if you are going, get a coupon book from the back of a taxi, they have a 2 for 1 ride.
Nice hotel but false advertising with the offer of wifi (part of 'resort fee'). No wifi available... Get with the times Paris.. Don't pay that fee if u come here... Get with it, Paris!

We got an upgrade to a suite for an extra $75 a night! Unbelievable! View of the strip from our window on the 32 nd floor, looking right at the Eiffel Tower with the Bellagio Fountains in the background. Friendly staff, pleasant frenchesque area with shops and restaurants, awesome location midstrip, decent sized sparsely populated pool. The suite helped make our first trip to Vegas fantastic.

Pretty enjoyable stay. Hotel is older, but still glamorous and plenty romantic. Great location, superb views, walking distance from everything. Many places to choose from as far as food and entertainment. FYI, valet parking at the hotel is free and it's the best way to do it, unless you want to drag your luggage through casino all by yourself for no good reason:). We saw a lot of people trying to save $5 for tip and ending up pretty pissed when they found out that the suffering could have been avoided:). 
Checking out could get tricky, so use express check-out if you can, to avoid 20-30 min wait.... Staff is helpful and knowledgeable. Do not use room phone for anything!  My kid called our cellphone, ended up paying $$$$$ for few minutes of airtime.

This is a tough call.  We really wanted to love this hotel, but it was just ok... My rating is more 3.5 stars but I'll bump it up to be nice!  Our room was not right upon arrival, but it could be to the fact that our flight was delayed and it was 1am when we checked in.  I highly recommend getting an upgrade (which we did pay for and got the following day).  The original rooms are dated...  Like the little couch was super disgusting... Reminded me of what you would find at a garage sale.  However the red rooms are more modern, elegant, clean, oh and the beds are comfy.We had an awesome view of the tower and the bellagio fountains.  One of my main issues was the casino... We aren't gamblers but we wanted to just have some fun and throw away a little extra cash.  The dealers we had at the roulette tables were weirdos.. One guy chatted our ears off about going out to dinner with his wife and mom.  I know it's a ploy to distract us, but it was terrible and ruined the moment to loosen up and relax.   We do highly recommend Gordon Ramsay Steak which is located in the hotel!

I am a Diamond player (black\/purple chip level) of several years with Paris and Caesars Entertainment who won't be coming back to patronize or play at this property. A few years ago, I really enjoyed coming and playing cards at the Paris. As of last week, I was thoroughly shocked at what I experienced at their hotel and casino. On the casino floor, every single dealer looked utterly miserable and unapproachable. They all stared and gave evil, dirty looks to players who were scoping out the tables as if to say, "Please don't sit down at my table!". I understand, there's a lot of interesting characters in Las Vegas and the dealers have to encounter and entertain a lot of people. However, that's no excuse for poor customer service because of that fact. Mind you, I'm 24 years old, so I know there's a stigma around young people that are going to Las Vegas, that we are all drunk party kids who come to Vegas to go crazy and get into trouble-- but that's not me. I'm dressed in designer clothes, I'm very professional & courteous to everyone. I'm not a trashed frat bro looking to play at a table and make a scene. This was middle of the day on a Sunday, too, not in the middle of the night. After dealing with Total Rewards and a cashier who didn't accept my initial signature to receive my freeplay, I walked up to a blackjack table to play the coupons I had. I found a mostly empty blackjack table and sat down. The angry dealer rolled her eyes at me and demanded my ID. She screamed for the pit boss to come and verify it before starting the game. I was polite and I understand the protocol they have in place. The floor woman was rude as well, even after handing her my Diamond card, which should at least tell them that I am a serious player. She was looking at my freeplay coupons as if I forged them at home and spent a good three minutes investigating it and researching my ID. When I placed the couple freeplay coupons on the betting circle, the dealer stared at me and said, "That's all you're going to bet?" in regard to my $25\/hand bet, tapped her hand on the table aggressively and slammed the cards down onto the table. The almost retired cocktail waitress then came by the table and requested our ID's, even though we weren't even ordering a drink. I was already sitting at a table with two friends. Why are we being carded again? OK, fine. But there's a polite way to do that. There has to be a better system so loyal younger guests don't feel harassed by bitter staff. Eventually, I lost the freeplay and I still smiled and thanked the miserable dealer. As I walked away, she told the other player loudly, "GOOD THING HE LOST!" What kind of comment is that in a casino? They judged me for being a young guest. However, I'm a very big tipper, so they are missing out. I have tipped dealers hundreds of dollars on a good run over the course of play. Maybe if she, or perhaps most dealers there, weren't so bitter & were nice to their players, maybe they would make tips and be a little more cheerful & happy as they made money playing with their guests. Then, the woman checking guests into the Diamond Lounge was rude to my friend and she left crying. I honestly thought this whole experience was a joke on me. Was the service at the Paris really this poor all around? I felt as if I was at some local card room, not a Las Vegas Caesars resort. Is this the type of customer service that Caesars Entertainment strives for? I would patronize their other properties, but Paris seems like the black sheep for their brand.

Once one of the nicest hotels in Las Vegas, but for $40 a night (Cyber Monday special) you can't complain.

My wife loved this place and I thought it was very good. Don't know what draws people to wait in line for that buffet, but maybe it is good...

Pros: friendly service, nice atmosphere in the lobby\/casino, Mon Ami Gabi (probably the best mid-priced steakhouse in Las Vegas), decent bathrooms, location on the strip quick elevators, pretty good dining options

Cons: outdated decor in room, TV's & channels offered (I'm not a tourist. I don't want international channels to replace cable), $25 gym & $15 wi-fi fee per day (no resort fees, but that's just ridiculous) 

For the price I'd return again. It's not at the level of a Mandalay or Palazzo, but for for half the price it's doable. We got Bally's for $38\/night in the summer and that place is a dump!

Stayed first 1 night and the experience was underwhelming and frustrating.  I will add that we used Expedia and paid for a red room with a view.  When we arrived, we overlooked a parking lot and could see Ballys next door.  The room was dingy.  Stains in tub, felt dirty, and the desk looked like a dog chewed it.  The mini fridge was also inoperable and the leather headboard was ripped.  Not exactly what I would call a "view" and certainly not as pictures online.  Called the hotel and they said I didn't have a reservation for a room with a view.  Spent almost 2 hours talking with Expedia who said all we needed to do was visit the front desk for a room key exchange because they worked everything out with the manager.  When my husband and I stopped at the desk to pick up keys, there was an arrogance to the employee who assisted us and after spending another 30 minutes in line\/explaining ourselves we got new keys but had to take a smoking rooms to get the Eiffel view we booked.  We told the desk worked that we still needed into the old room to get our bags, but when we got to the original room the keys were deactivated - we went straight there!  Used the hallway phone to call back to the desk because it's a long walk and was told nobody could help me and that I would have to walk back to the lobby, wait in line, and then talk to somebody again.  Needless to say, that wasn't an acceptable answer, especially when I was treated like I was in the wrong.  Finally got a security gaurd to let us into the room and a food\/beverage credit for the inconvenience.  Check into room 2 and it was unsurprisingly much the same as the first.  It reminds me of decor you would find in a house in the 90s.  The clock and phone are outdated, curtains dirty, etc.  Also, the pillows in room 2 were lumpy and the bed linens didn't feel fresh.  I used the towel in the bathroom to wipe up some water on the sink and the towel turned black when I did.  I don't suggest staying here.  Check it out to gamble, got to Beer Park, but don't stay here!

We saw the Jersey Boys here on the last day before their winter break, and really enjoyed the hotel setting and atmosphere.  Chandeliers adorn the lobby to the showroom and a row of former telephone booths serves as some quite seating for those who don't like crowds.  The casino is quite active, with several crap tables and slots on the way to the lobby, and all were quite paying off with the jingle of coins and shouts from the table.  Being on the strip, it is the most visible on the east side of the street, with the huge tower as a point of reference for many tourists.

I've not ever stayed in the hotel, so I can't comment on the rooms or the service at the front desk....

However, I've been here many times.  A couple of times for shows and a few times with out of town friends.

First of all, the parking garage is HORRIBLE.  Whoever designed it should be shot.  The garage is also shared by Bally's next door, which is hugely inconvenient if you are going to that property.

I am very confused by the location of the theater.  It's literally in the lobby of the front desk, on the back side of the hotel.  It gets VERY crowded at showtime and there just isn't enough space for all of those people.  And don't get be started on the bar at the theater - what a nightmare!

I remember way back in the day when this hotel first opened, and I was in town for a volleyball tournament, being a tourist.  We walked from MGM to Paris to check it out and I loved it!  Now, not so much.  The cobblestone is just a bad idea, although I appreciate the concept.

Because it's the strip, the table limits are high, the slots are too tight and the drink service is slow.  Not a great place for locals.

Outside of the never ending conventioneers sporting matching polos, lanyards, and mustaches, Paris is actually a neat place to stay... It's clean, on the strip, and has a couple of nice restaurants to boot.

My stays have been primarily in their Calais Suites, so I may be a bit biased, but the appointments in the room are quite nice. Great bed, nice jacuzzi tub, and double bathrooms make for a pleasant experience.

The staff at Paris has always been kind and easy going, from the bell staff, to the house keeping, all smiles... Perhaps it's the tipping that makes them elated, but I appreciate the warmth nevertheless...

After a week at Paris, I was definitely ready for a trip home... Thanks Vegas for another week of mayhem, marvel, and staying moonstruck throughout it all.

The hotel and rooms reeked of smoke. There are so many hotels on the Strip that do a better job of ventilation. The rooms are standard and compare to that of three star hotel at best. The location however saves this place. Very centrally located on the strip.

Very nice hotel. Received great service at check in and by the pool. For $50 you can get a strip view which includes private snack are, free drinks and 10% off spa services. If you use them, it wouldn't be a bad deal. The pool has a great view of the Eiffel tower and other parts of the strip. Rooms are very nice and comfortable. Not the best luxury on the strip, however it's a very nice place to stay. 

I love the ambiance of the casino. It's nice to stay here and be able to walk downstairs to enjoy the casino. The little shops add a nice touch as well. The restaurant is very good, expensive and good, however my favorite thing there is the souffle. You can go there for just dessert however you won't be seated at a main table, you can eat at the bar.

So romantic at night at the top of the Eiffel Tower.  Husband proposed to me there.  Has great food (excellent French toast in a little bistro there across from the Paris buffet). It's easy to get to if you're using the monorail (since it's one of the stops).  Definitely a place I'd recommend.

Wow where the hell do I start?!! WELL THIS IS MY 100TH REVIEW!! Perfect too because we had such an excellent time in their casino. Well I think we did, I was pretty wasted. Actually we had such a good time we missed our flight. I do not remember much.. It is sort of a blur of flashing lights, a steady stream of alcohol, cigars being smoked, money being won and almost immediately lost, hardcore laughs and finally a waitress named Tina and a bartender named Kyle. I remember we started with roulette. My cousin was up $250. We celebrated at the bar with Kyle the Mix-ologist. I think He wowed us with his amazing handcrafted drinks & amused us with his interesting conversation. I think we talked about UFO'S and cigars. After that we wanted cigars so he pointed us to the nearest Davidoff where we picked out whatever since we know nothing of cigars. After that we started parading through the casino like drunkards in search of a good slot machine. I remember I kept bursting out " I wanna 777 machine" so that's what we looked for.  Once we found the perfect slot machine we nestled in for the long haul and that's where we encountered Tina. Oh Tina... If you only knew the chain of events that were sparked by your liquor generosity you would surely laugh at us. Tina came by while we were playing slots and told us the drinks were complimentary. It felt like Christmas morning. We started with Heineken. It took a little long the 1st time but once she came back we gave her a $20. She never went to far after that. We ended up drinking, Heineken, Fireball shots, Gin and tonic & vodka cranberry until we finally settled on patron shots. We had about 4 patron shots after all that and then our limo arrived... Sadly we did not make it home to Chicago that day... and all that Free  liquor did not stay down.... One of the best days of my life!!
I love Paris Vegas. Always pretty to get a nice view. The staff is always nice. The rooms are clean. I just dont like it when the casino takes my money. Thats why its 4 stars instead of 5.

We stayed in the Paris Luxury Suite and can I just say I was very impressed. We stepped off of the elevator into a semi-private (only 4 other doors) very elegant corridor with breath taking views.
 We had a double door entrance that opened up to marble floors and Italian furnishings. The suite was about 900sq feet with a formal dining area, wet bar, powder room, whirlpool tub, private dressing area, separate bedroom and a bathroom with a bidet. There was a great view of the eiffel tower with the water show from the Bellagio Hotel in the background from the living and bedroom area. 

The hotel itself was reminiscent of Paris with quaint boutiques and restaurants. We hit Burger Brasserie for dinner, La Creperie for dessert and this cute little wine store for a bottle and took everything back to the room.
All in all we had a great time although I did find it difficult to walk on the cobble stone in my heels.

I wish I could give this place zero stars, but Yelp does not allow that. 

This was THE WORST RESORT EXPERIENCE we have ever dealt with.

We flew in on a Friday night for a 5 night stay for our anniversary. They do not offer transportation to and from the airport, so you have to find a shuttle. The shuttles go to EVERY hotel on the strip and on a Friday night this takes lots of time. It took us nearly two hours to get to the Paris. 

We were dropped off at a side alley way next to their Casino entrance. If you are a nonsmoker, be prepared. The stench in the Casino truly makes it smell like Paris, in a bad way. We're already exhausted from having taken a cross country flight and now we have to be subjected to the casino while trying to find our way to check in. I'm sure the purpose of this is to get you to start playing the slots upon your arrival. 

In any case, it took us 15 minutes to find the check-in area as their signage is poor at best. 

I let the person checking us in know that we are there for our anniversary and wanted to see if they had a way to upgrade us, if not, no big deal. Then, the clerk goes into this long-winded explanation about a room for $80 per night - or so I thought at first. It was $80 additional per night I later figured out. I signed and headed up to the room. 

It's about 1am when we get to the room (4am from our time zone). The room itself was good. It was on the 29th floor overlooking the strip and their Eiffel Tower Restaurant. Then, it hit us. The thumping of music from their club, 26 floors below us. There was nothing they could do about it since it was a normal Friday night. They offered us earplugs - really? Ever sleep with earplugs? Kind of uncomfortable. 

It took about 90 minutes for us to finally fall asleep. 

Next morning, I went to take a shower and found hairs on the drain and along the side of the shower. It seems the shower wasn't cleaned correctly. Housekeeping could have cared less. We didn't have time to argue as we had shows and other things to do.  

During our time in their shopping and restaurant area, you could still smell the smoke from the nearby casino. It killed any romance we would like to have had walking through their indoor courtyard.

Things came to a head on Sunday morning when my wife wanted to work out in their fitness center. They told her it would cost $25 per day! We were pissed and wanted out. 

At first, the management wanted to charge us an early checkout fee. After an argument, they relented and we called the Palazzo down the street. 

Read my review of them for more!

Just spent the weekend at the Paris Hotel and it was a great experience.  Paris has excellent food and rooms for the price. 
 You gotta go to Mon Ami Gabi.  Great restaurant!  Blood Mary Bar. Food was great and service was good too.  The escargot was awesome! The bill was very reasonable for Las Vegas dining on the strip.

Another one of my favorite places to play!  I've been pretty lucky at the tables of Paris!  BJ, baby, that's my game!!  Very relaxing casino setup with the high ceilings, painted blue sky and clouds, makes ya feel that much closer to floating away after a few drinks!  Dealers are hit and miss but I do remember chatting it up with a few awesome dealers, makes taking my $$ a little less painful!  The surrounding restaurants and shops are cool too!

Great. Huge rooms amazing casino withdancers. Many authentic French restaurants. Great staff and fantastic pool party.  If Paris pool party is lame go across the road to Caesars. I was here for two convention.free parking was great too

Over priced! No free Wifi. Each iPhone or iPad costs $14.95 ea. for 24 hr. My wife and I (2-iPhones & 2-iPads) $60 just to use Wifi for 24hrs. Rip-Off. FYI room was old, mirror off wall. Room needs complete update.
A bit above average, i'd say 3.5 stars.  nothing exordinary, but comfortable and had all the basic amenities.  Great buffet tho, which i'll write in a separate review.

My fifth time to Vegas. Took the family this time as I was in business next door at PH for a convention.  Room was nice but the air conditioner didn't work worth a lick. Said 60 but was likely 75. Made sleeping difficult.  Should have complained but already unpacked. Did go to the pool one day with the kids. They enjoyed.  Great location convenient to most of the strip. Was ok and might stay here again but probably look elsewhere just to see something different.

Are there fancier hotels to stay in Vegas? Sure, but where else can you look out your window and see the Eiffel Tower?! The rooms were very neat and clean. The shower was nicely updated and tiled. The casino and check-in area definitely has the wow factor for the first time Vegas goers. It has a "family friendly" vibe. They have a convenient little store right by the elevators in case you need any late night medicine or snacks.

Just stayed overnight at the Paris for the first time this past Saturday.  I have visited the casino in the past, so I already knew it's basic layout.  This was my first time staying in one of their rooms. I got a room with two queen beds and was pleased with the room size and cleanliness. The bathroom really impressed me with it's size and decor. I loved the separate tub and shower. The vanity had ample counter space for the standard array of ladies toiletries. I just wish hotels would equip their bathrooms with ventilation fans to help clear out the humidity and, um, other bathroom odors.

The TV is mounted to the wall, but it's way off center to accomodate the large armoire on the same wall. The armoire has two closet doors and three drawers to place clothing in. There is also a mini fridge in one of the cabinets in the armoire. I then realized the bathroom was so spacious because there was no built in closet, the armoire is your closet. It actually works because the armoire is French, and being the Paris hotel, it makes sense decor wise.

The beds were comfortable and the headboard was padded faux leather. It was nice because I often sit up in bed with my head resting against the headboard. The decorative pillows on the bed were too much though. Two very large brown velour covered pillows and one bolster pillow. So actually there were only two small pillows that had pillowcases on them to lay your head and sleep on. I wouldn't sleep on the velour ones as I doubt those get changed like the sheets do.

There is wi-fi included for two devices with the "resort package" which I think means the "resort fee," and you can have more with an additonal fee. The TV channel selection was limited and kind of in an odd sequence. They have groups of six elevators each to service the different sections of floors, and they were quite speedy. 

The employees I encountered from valet, bell service, and front desk were all well-mannered and helpful. I would definitely stay here again.

AMAZING interior...felt like I was in a completely different space. The buffet was good...and the EIffel tower full of strawberry Margarita was yummy! Definitely a fun visit. Didn't stay here though, so not sure what that is like, however like I said, I think the interior is pretty freaking cool.

Laying here on the last day with the night approaching, I look back on our trip and had an excellent trip. Always loved the casino and the energy of the entire place. First time staying here at Paris, our view was perfect, facing the strip, Bellago fountains right out the window, and can see the pool. Room is nice, service has been good (checking in that's all we used them for) room was big and clean. Had a refrigerator and coffee pot, both of which were not in other hotels. Job well done Paris. It's by far the best hotel I've stayed in and don't know if I will want to stay in other one's on the strip. Hate to leave but made it memorable.

Love the location of this hotel. We and my buddies go out for March Madness. This year we picked Paris. We got a great deal. We liked the hotel for the location, but went to other hotels to gamble. We did not stay at the hotel during the day, nor much at night. its a good place to stay, but for action you will need to go somewhere else.

Stayed March 2011

Let me start by saying that I was on a business trip and had limited hotels to choose from. This one is centrally located and that's where the benefits of staying here end.
I had made reservations online for myself and 7 of my colleagues. The person on the phone was nice enough, but they do charge a deposit when you book multiple rooms (I do not know if this is the process when booking a singular room).  When asked how my deposit would be returned, she said not to worry, just tell them at the front desk upon check-in. I reiterated this to my colleagues who did just that upon arrival. Unfortunately, one of my colleagues got Priscilla who was not having a good day and took her wrath out on us. Apparently, either she or her computer system cannot perform tasks like "refund" or "cancel transaction" because it took an act of Congress for her to refund my deposit. I'm still not certain that it was done properly. She chose to punish me by telling me I didn't get an upgrade whilst my colleague behind me did (for just an additional $20 extra). I guess she gets her kicks off wielding that kind of power. 
I tried to call the central reservation line, but I got the runaround there, too. So my advice to you if you are booking a large party here is - don't. Go somewhere else where they value their customers. This isn't the place. 
Also, the room I was given was dirty and I wouldn't dare step on the carpet with bare feet. The housekeeping staff was friendly enough, but I found some trash in the drawers of the desk (including a hospital bracelet - yikes!). The bathroom never was truly cleaned...but I figured complaining would get me nowhere. Next time I'm in Vegas, I will stay elsewhere. There's nothing at the Paris hotel that I can't live without. If you can swing it - the Bellagio never disappoints.
Never stay in the end room, the whole room smell likes public restroom! I changed room three times. The staff is not that professional, need more training!

I remember when this was one of the nicest hotels on the Strip. Like Napoleon, those days are long gone.

The rooms still have tube tvs, and some of the finishes look well worn. 

The elevators reek of cigarette smoke. 

The pool area has cracks on the pavement. 

The customer service is good overall, but you are starting to get what you pay for.

They charge $15 a day for Internet, and $25 a day if you use it in the business center.  

I went to the coffee shop to ask for a cup of hot water, and they charge $4.  Really?  You've got to be kidding.

I spent 6 nights here & loved it.  It is really a beautiful hotel\/casino.  Check in for us was quick & painless.  We were there 6 nights and never had one complaint.  We opted out of the "extras" liek internet & gym use.  I heard it can get pricey so we used one of the cafes located in the hotel that offered free WiFi if we needed it.  I didn't really shop around other casinos, I went for a wedding and chose the Paris because that is where the wedding party was staying and since I was in the wedding I wanted to be close.  I booked throught Southwest.com Vegas Jackpot deals and I think we did ok price wise.  Some of the resturants were Meh...a couple were phenominal (sp?).  The architecture is so pretty and the pool was nice and cold on a hot day.

This hotel is nice on the outside, but the rooms are tiny on the inside.  I felt claustrophobic.  I just like lots of room.  I may be petite but I still like spacious especially since Las Vegas is known to go BIG!  Casino is fine, rooms are small...  You decide...

Stayed there for a week long conference. prices at their bar downstairs are ridiculously expensive. Hotel overall seemed kind of run down and dirty. Service was ok. 

I'd rather stay at the Bellagio.

The outside decor is beautiful with the Eiffel Tower, fountains, huge Paris balloon, and the Mon Ami restaurant right on the sidewalk.  Once you enter the Hotel you are immediately drawn to the fresh bakery smell of bread\/croissants and desserts.  There are cobble stone walkways throughout the hotel but that's where it ends. 

The casino has a strange vibe to it and different layout.  I'm not a fan of the inside of this Hotel as it seems they spent a lot of money on the outside but just crammed slot machines everywhere.  

I flew in with my wife on our anniversary to see Tony Bennett in concert (awesome) and had a corner suite on the highest floor.  The room was way above average with a dinning table, separate bed room with a LCD that rises out of the foot of the bed, nice bathroom, and decent size sitting area.  The view was spectacular and I must commend the room service food was extremely good.  Definitely a solid 4 star resort, not the biggest, but definitely top 10.   The food here is way beyond expectations as we tried all the restaurants including the steak house and were more than satisfied.

The worst hotel on the strip unless you enjoy poor service, an extremely slow check Ballys gaming company, who operates the hotel.. It took 48 minutes to check in. 

I would stay at an MGM or WYNN property before ever staying here. 

I have a laundry list of issues from starting up the iron to iron my clothes and it not working. 45 minutes later getting a replacement to getting water from the hall way vending machine for $3.00 and it not dispensing water. I called the front desk and they state, sorry, we can't help you. 

Worst hotel on the strip bar none.

Arrived in Vegas for the girls trip 2 days ahead of the ladies... gave me a little "me" time to have fun solo which is always a nice change of pace... decided to stay at the Paris Hotel solo since I got a great deal on the room!

Arrived aroudn 12:30AM and of course there was no one else in line to check in... so checking in was fast with no complications. I knew my way around the hotel since I've been to Vegas before so that was a plus to navigate around the hotel.

GREAT VIEW of the Bellagio fountains!

Went up to my room on the 24th floor? I think lol... it was average and cute. Queen beds since I checked in late and all the king beds were taken. All the usual amenities: nightstand with clock, desk with chair and writing materials, TV, mini bar, tub, stand up shower, toilet, double sink, coffee machine, hair dryer etc... Nothing fancy but not lacking any simple essentials. The elevators to the hotel rooms and the parking garage are fairly close (for being in a Vegas hotel!) together so that was nice. Parking was always available. The hotel is clean, the staff is friendly, and I'd recommend this place for others to stay at.

 I've been up to the Eiffel Tower on my last visit with my boyfriend. Breathtaking view of Vegas! 

The only negative I'd say... the walls are a little thin. By the time I got settled, gambled a little, and went to bed (tired after the flight etc)... a bunch of party goers came back to their room somewhere near me but it was SO loud... the walls should be thicker! That's the only thing I didn't like and that's enough to deter me from staying again BUT if you don't mind that then it's definitely a nice play to stay!

Check out at 10:30AM on a Friday morning was fast and easy.

1 Night Stay (Fri-Sat)

Pros:
Central Location
Free Self Parking

Cons: 
Dirty Room
Room needs updating
Poor air ventilation
Rude, unhelpful staff
No counter space in the bathroom

Conclusion:
Don't stay here, would not recommend.

This place is overcrowded you can barely move around on the casino floor. The room was clean the water pressure is terrible. This is a real nickel and dime operation. The are cheap on the water pressure like they are cheap on the Internet connection. You select "free" internet and they bill you for it telling you the convention you are visiting for hasn't paid the resort fee. Of course you can't discover that until you have already incurred the cost. Shameless when an enormous money maker like this resort does this stupid stuff. Bad management people Im staying elsewhere next time.

Our room at Paris was robbed, they took a laptop and some other electronics.  

It isn't a sure thing that Paris employees were responsible - though it is more likely than not, since there was no forced entry - but the Paris security staff had no interest in helping us.  The security guy said that he had never in ten years seen a situation where a maid robbed a room.  It might not happen frequently, but to suggest it never happens is ridiculous.  (And when the theft was reported to the cops, the officer said maids are often responsible for theft at hotels.)  

The Paris security staff also discouraged us from reporting the matter to the police, wouldn't tell us when key cards had been used to access our room, wouldn't tell us if they found anything from reviewing their security tapes, and generally did little other than CYA.  

I'm sure there is some theft at every hotel.  But the way the Paris staff handled it made it much worse.

This is one of the Las Vegas specialty casino's. They are modeled around the idea of a Paris theme. They have some small specific details which make the interior pop. The exterior features a model of the Eiffel tower which has an elevator to the top that you can utilize for sight seeing purposes. This is a nice place to attend for a quiet romantic vibe, and its perfect for photos and stuff like that.

I was impressed with this hotel start to finish.

The lady checking us in at the front desk was very friendly and helpful.  She alerted us to the convention coming in on our checkout day and suggested measures to avoid long waits. She gave us a corner room (which I learned can be identified with a P following the room number) and I'm pretty sure those corner rooms are significantly bigger than (or at least have more windows) than standard rooms.

The casino isn't bad, and if you're looking for more variety, it's short walk to the connected Bally's hotel and casino.

Le Village Buffet, part of Paris, is a nice buffet option, and offers the good deal of unlimited food\/visits for 24 hours for about 45 bucks. The Mon Ami Gabi, at the front of Paris, is a great place for a nicer meal. 

Everything seemed clean and tidy in the room. I hardly even took advantage of all the amenities this hotel has to offer, but I look forward to a return visit.

I have stayed at 10 hotels in Vegas but for some reason not Paris (likely the same reason I'd never stayed at the NY\/NY, I've been to both cities and kind of hate the gimmicks of these types of hotels offer) but I have to say I was pleasantly pleased. We had upgraded the rooms prior to arrival to the red rooms, higher floors with nicer views supposedly and I liked what we got, though of course with its location you hope for a room facing the Eiffel Tower and the Bellagio fountain but instead we got the roof of the casino and the back of the Planet Hollywood.  
I think what I was most pleased about was the food and beverage options we had. The crepe\/pastry shop, Mon ami Gabi and Hexx were all spectacular choices, the menu was very appropriate for the hotels theme. 

I didn't experience the pool and gym so I can't really comment on it but I've been told the Paris pool is very so-so, keep in mind if a big pool is a must for you. You might wanna consider MGM, Mandalay, Venetian, Flamingo and Mirage as options instead. 

Overall though a great experience. Glad I finally stayed there.

I stayed there for 1 night. The hotel was very nice. The room and the bathroom was clean. 
while I was checking in we had to wait in a very long line! The front desk person informed me that they don't have 2 beds in the room as I requested, however they were willing to give me an upgrate with a nicer view. We were ok with that. The hotel stuff was very friendly.
the only thing I didn't like was that I could hear people in the hallway closing doors. I think there was a party in the next room that involved many people walking in and out. Afterall, it's Vegas.

There are many great things to say about the Paris Hotel. I am not a Las Vegas fan in general but business commitments dictate conference locations. Every employee encounter was pleasant with helpfulness and kindness. They were very accommodating since 2 colleagues had not made room reservations, the hotel provided a suite at a reasonable price. On arrival 9\/25\/15 there was a very long delay being on hold since at check in I had requested 2 rollaway beds and near bed time they still had not arrived. Also very accommodating with blankets and towels. The room carpet is old and could use replacement. The elegance of their drapes in design are hampered by the tears and worn appearance. The artifical flowers need fresh water as well if you know what I mean. Thank you Paris Hotel.
It was okay. The beds were shitty. There was only 1 pool. The pool chairs were cheap. However, there was a nice view from our room.

So far not impressed :(. Wanted to stay here for Sooo many years. We are here with a large group of family to celebrate a 21st bday. First off the lady who checked us in was so rude. AND checking in at 2pm they charge $15! I've been coming to Vegas my whole life and this has NEVER happened, really?? On top of the $20 resort fee?? Really? And the lady could care less. Our second room couldn't be on the same floor either. Oh could we get a view? $30 bucks. Now to the room...old, dingy, bathroom run down with hard water crusted around the shower. I'm shocked and disappointed so far :(.

You would think being one of the bigger themed Harrahs themed properties, this place would be good...I beg to differ! Rooms were cheap and cheesy. Pools were nothing thrilling and the restaurants were only fair! We ate at the effil tower restaurant and they had the nerve to charge 48$ for rack of lamb and they give TWO lollipop pieces of lamb...literally 4 bites for 50$...what a joke! You could stay at Harrahs, Balys or flamingo, pay much less and get a similar experience!

They took part of France and plopped it in the middle of Vegas..including the very blue sky with wispy clouds that almost seemed to move as you made your way through streets of Paris. Lots of shops and typical mall prices.

i've been to paris many times and seen the eiffel tower in numerous occasions...ummm, not the city paris in france, but the hotel in las vegas.  i never stayed at the hotel as a guest, but did many things in there the city tourism bureau encouraged (ironically, i've technically been to paris, at least its charles de gaulle airport, quite a few times en route to my other destinations).  the hotel itself is beautiful with quite ornate details and decorations a person can easily overlook.  it has its charm and coziness that are not found in many of these extravagantly huge hotels now being built around and its cleanliness cannot be compared to those old, dingy hotels that once had seen their own glorious times back in the days.

We waited around at the hotel casino bar since they wouldn't let us check in earlier than 10 am.  i had no idea a tequila shot could cost over $13...what a buzz kill :).  my sister who watches way too much csi wanted a room close to the elevators (something about dr. grissom saying how crimes always happen in rooms far far away from easy access to elevators...it doesn't make sense logically!).  our room which was around the corner of the elevators was pretty quiet and clean, but bit on the smaller size.  the bathroom had a separate shower and tub, and i have to give a major credit for its hairdryer.  it wasn't one of those small white miniature size one.  it actually was a salon size one with full blowing power!!!  the water pressure was really weak so if you are one of those who does everything in shower, you might anger your friends (i don't get people who take shower longer than 15 minutes...do you not shower every day???  what do you do in there???).  i didn't like the bed at all (too hard for me), but i think every hotel in vegas uses uncomfortable beds so the guests go out and spend their money instead of staying in their rooms.

my sister, the bf and i decided to hit the pool while waiting for some friends.  the pool itself was pretty small, but there were many chaises to lounge around.  we ordered a mega size (32 oz) margarita along with some food to cool us down from the blasting heat wave.  those waitresses wearing a short mini skirt were definitely eye candies to some guys (you can see their eyes moving from one direction to another, and some obvious guys move their entire heads!!!).  i initially thought the food was overpriced, but there was a lot of food and tasted better than i had expected.

after hunger's gone, thirst hits, and my sister decided to get a bottle of water.  a few minutes later, she came back with tears in her eyes...almost.  she told us how rude the bartender was (for more details, you can read this - http:\/\/www.yelp.com\/user_details_review_search?userid=uVUCqySWrgIZdiJG1a6R_Q&q=paris).  i got up and went directly to the same guy, not because i wanted to revenge but i seriously needed some water (sorry, sis :)).  he didn't ask for my i.d. to talk to him nor to buy a $6 bottle of water, but he definitely wasn't a friendly guy.  honestly, it was all a blur after that 32oz margarita, and i couldn't get really angery at the guy who threw some sh*t at my sister because i am a happy drinker.  i am sure we called for the manager on duty and the sis and bf resolved the issue somehow...

right in the middle of the strip, paris hotel has a prime location.  the miracle mile shopping center (old aladdin, now planet hollywood) is right next door and caesar's palace's forum is just across the street.  i didn't get to enjoy any amenities the hotel had offered except the hairdryer and pool.  although i had a great time in vegas, that memory really isn't associated with my stay at paris hotel.  our experience at the pool rather left me a sour taste and i probably won't come back to this hotel where an employee isn't property trained in customer service.  sure, it's cheaper and less luxurious than others, but if it means i have to pay more to get better services, then i will!!!

Ooh la la! My stay here was short, but oh-so-nice. 

The front desk was informative and friendly, and even gave us a fancy corner room, which was a little larger than the normal room, came with two sets of windows, separate shower and jacuzzi tub, and a big, comfy bed. And I love all the red decor. I can't say I took advantage of any of those things other than flopping into bed that night, but the friendliness of staff, cleanliness of the room, and decent price definitely work in favor of me booking here again.

The table games at the casino seemed to average at $15 minimums, with some rare $10 tables thrown in during the day. They had most of the "hot new" slot machines. (I say "most" because I could not find the Lobstermania2 penny slot in Paris OR Bally's.) 

Mon Ami Gabi is also located in Paris, and that restaurant is fabulous, and probably my only "must visit" in Vegas.

I was very skeptical about staying at a themed hotel because of the kitsch factor, but I trust my sil's suggestions. She never steers me wrong when it comes to vacation.

I adore la Paris. As far as themed hotels go, the placing of the Eiffel, Arche de Triompe, the musems et al are done scalefully (no such word) and skillfully. Pipe in some Edith Piaf and it's a thrill. What an adult DisneyWorld.

I don't find the beds hard at all. Sure, they are not plushy and all down-feathered, but it is not shabby. I got a good night's sleep out of it. As far as fridge goes, there's one but NO ROOM for stuff. Try moving anything to make room, it registers as a purchase, so I'm told. So don't touch anything. 

The concierge is helpful, and looked up various show times and restaurant reservations for us.

The casino area is not huge, but for a non-big-time gambler like me, I'm OK. If you want to gamble within the premises, the Paris is joined underground to the Bally's. They, along with Rio, Flamingo, Caesar's Palace, are owned by the same corporation. You can get a free bus ride to those properties. 

Although there are other elegant choices along the Strip, the Paris definitely ranks as one of the better ones to put one's feet up for its central location, it being right across from the Bellagio.

*Photos shot

Check in was not well staffed and had a lengthy wait. Close to thirty minutes. No free wifi. 14.95 per day for a connection. Cleaning clothes left in bathroom. Room was very nice and clean. Linens were fresh. Would probably not stay here again

When ur looking for a hotel its all about location location location.  Paris hotel is in prime location.  Obvioiusly, not the nicest hotel on the strip but its in the middle of everything...directly across the street from the Bellagio.  It's not really a place for young people as the Chateau night club isn't the most happening spot on the strip.  Poolside is decent...right below the Eifel Tower.  Glass elevator brings you up to the Eifel tower restaurant on its 11th floor....excellent French food...great ambiance...great layout and great view of the Bellagio fountains.  Like I said...the hotel is not the greatest scene of the strip, but a decent place to rest your head considering its in the best location on the strip...in the middle of everything!  Great place for people in their 40's and 50's.

While in a covenant location. The tv did not work and nothing in the room is updated. Additionally there is no closet. If you are looking for a place to sleep and are planning to go elsewhere for fun then it is a great hotel but I expected more from such an expensive hotel

As we arrived to the hotel there was a pretty convenient set up for the valet, you could either self park or get your car valeted (which was complimentary since we were going to stay at the hotel). Going in to check in was also petty nice, the woman was very nice and helpful. As we arrived to the room all went down hill from there. I had requested a room with a view of the strip but as I opened the blinds what I saw was a parking lot (so disappointing). I decided to look around and make sure everything was clean but sadly it wasn't.. Not only was there hair in the tub but the coffee machine, coffee, and tea was set in the restroom.Will not be returning to this hotel, definitely not worth spending your money here. I really Tried to ignore these flaws, the next morning as we opened the door the smell of weed was KILLER (we had requested a non smoking section). I understand the casino is full of smoke but I don't think the hallway should be smelling like pot. That morning we ordered breakfast, it took a little longer than expected but I chose to not let it bother me. The man that brought up our breakfast for us was so rude! I had never in my life experienced anything like this, my father tipped him and he looked down shook his head and walked away. First of all a tip was not required but out of being considerate my father did so (he really shouldn't have). This was supposed to be my parents anniversary get away and it turned out to be a disaster!!! Not happy and feel like my money went down the drain.
Very pretty place, but still lacking visible drink service.  Had to deal with beggars and religious people blocking the entry.  Classy indeed.
Exceeded expectations.  An older hotel- but very nice for the $$.  Last year we stayed at New York, New York, and I believe Paris in nicer.

3.5 STARS.

I must say, stayed at the Paris a few times already and this place never really seems to disappoint. The staffs at pretty much any place in this hotel are nice. The rooms are nice and you can find the rooms at pretty cheap rates from time to time.

As for dining, that'll be reviewed at a later time.

CONS: 

1.) The Paris caters to an older crowd. 

2.)No young dance clubs except for a live band bar in the casino floor playing Tayo Cruz (blah), Usher and Top 40s hip hop.

3.)  Late night casino tables has 2-$10 black jack tables. For a cheapo like me (sorry), I'll start off with $10 and feel the dealer up a bit first before I up it to $25 a hand when I'm rollin.

But that's about it. I am a fan of Paris and the Harrah's card program. But I'd wish they'd have more nightly entertainment bars, venues, clubs in the hotel. I guess I have to walk next door to PH for that. 

Their buffet use to be TOPS, but I think they've gone down a bit. The "Le Cafe" is ok. The breakfast menu is a bit small.

I have been to this hotel many times, but recently stayed there for my first time. The rooms are not as fabulous as I anticipated. They just didn't seem that clean. 

This hotel seems to be busy at all hours of the day and night. It's expensive and there really are no breaks at this hotel. 

The Eiffel Tower ride was awesome as the view of the strip was amazing. You can see the airport as well.

The service standard a disappointment but the worst part was there was no hot water for the shower!!!! I was pretty upset, never had this happen before and I stayed at a lot of hotels. It's a nice establishment but those are some things I can't over look

Please , please stay away from this hotel! This has been the worst hotel and customer service experience my wife and I have had in 20 years. We have had better service at motel 6. Where do I start? My wife and I stayed in mid July for a week. We waited in line to be checked in for a half hour we get to our rooms my wife's card key was not working. We went back down to the concierge who would not help us with there mistake but told us to stand in another line which took another 20 mins to take  8 seconds to fix the card. The elevators were not working properly half the escalators were not working. The toilet clogged on the 2nd day. House keeping would leave some of our blankets and pillows on the floor when they made the bed not once twice but 3 times. Garbage was not taken out and forget about getting enough towels. We had a better TV cable package at motels after we left for our road trip. The room was dinged up the whole hotel had a dingy dirty look to it Forget about asking the concierge desk any question they either did not know answers to question then gave you this look as to WHY ARE YOU BOTHERING ME? A friend of ours that was staying at the hotel the same week as us slipped outside of the hotel on their property from the water misters body slammed on the concrete they refused to pay for a cab to the hospital for her. When we left to go on our road trip in the early AM my wife discovered she had left her sweater back on the bed. We called the hotel 5am they said they would send some one up to retrieve it so we could pick it up when we came back through Vegas in a week. Guess what? No sweater was ever logged in.

Rude condescending staff along with grubby, moldy smelling rooms. We had requested a queen standard room with Eiffel Tower view.  When we arrived we were checked in by a man named Casey who so rude and condescending.  We had told him we had requested a room with a view and he looked down at me and said, "well, that's just it, a request is just a request, isn't it?"  We were stuck in a pokey corner room next to back staircase room 1073. Called down asked for manager and spoke to a so called manager named Brittney. She said exact same thing that a request is just a request and too bad.  I called her back had told her we can't stay in this filthy room. She told me to come back down and lo and behold Mr. Personality changed our room to exact room but 10 floors up room 2297.  Filthy, moldy, and weird entry as room seems cut in half and could hear people next door. It was 2:00 am and exhausted so stayed there but didn't unpack.  First thing I called and we changed our room again. Better room but I seriously think if these reviews are ready by management they should be aware of how rude their staff are.  These are staff that represent their hotel. We will go to Vegas again but will not stay at Paris.

Very nice hotel. Very clean rooms. But the people working there are sooooo rude! The ladies in the cafe are not very friendly or helpful. We went to buy a croissant at JJ Bolangerie and they can't even help us heat it up as they said they were too busy. My kids don't eat cold croissants and I specifically asked if it could be heated before I purchased it and the Cashier told me yes, but when I went to actually asked for it to be heated, they said they were too busy. Then we called the front desk to check out. The lady helping us check out was soooo rude and condensing. We paid for our valet and I HAD the receipt in my hand and she said she cannot find a record of it in the system. She said we if we paid at valet, there is no way she can tell if we paid or not...seriously? They don't have a integrated system? We had to go walk to valet and talk to the guys there..she said she couldn't help us. I would love to day here again as th location is good and clean Hotel but the staff needs better training..

As a Diamond card holder of the Total Rewards program with Harrah's, I get lots of offers for free rooms in Vegas, including Paris.  I love to stay here and it always feels like "home" for me on the strip.  Love the location and the service is always consistently good.  I especially like that this casino is not HUGE, but just big enough (as compared to Ceasar's where I find myself wandering in circles at night looking for the right tower and elevator to just get to bed!  Wait...maybe that has something to do with 12 hours of consistent drinking....hmmm...ok, well...).  I love the red rooms at Paris and have also stayed in the Penthouse suite a few years ago (which was a nice treat and a comp upgrade).  The Diamond Lounge is nice because it's easily accessible and they have hot apps in the afternoon and always free cocktails.  

I'll sum it up with:  Le Paris est magnifique!

After making a reservation and doing an online pre checkin, I thought our room would actually be reserved. When I arrived and tried to use the automated kiosk, it claimed the room was unavailable and I would need to wait. This is at 10pm with a tired 2 year old. Checkin only had 1 employee working with a huge line. Avoid this hotel if you value your sanity. The hotel employee claimed that management fired most of the check-in staff and tried to replace them with automated kiosks (which don't work, apparently).

Edit: Apparently, that was just the beginning. There were many other minor things that made this seem more like a 2 star hotel than a major Las Vegas brand.

1) The fridge in the room barely worked (slightly cooler than room temperature). Maybe it was operator error, but I don't think so. I'm pretty sure I can manage to adjust the temperature on a fridge correctly. 

2) I tried to make a reservation at the hotel's restaurant for breakfast. The official website linked to OpenTable, but it said it was "unable to make a reservation at this time." So I tried calling on the phone. My first question, of course, was "how long is the wait without a reservation on average?" Seems simple enough right? Well, apparently this hotel has outsourced their restaurant calls to a call center! So naturally, the person had no information whatsoever. The only thing they could do was make a reservation. Which, by the way, took about 10 minutes to accomplish once you include the ridiculous phone tree, reading off a gigantic rewards number several times, listening to the cancellation policy (for a RESTAURANT RESERVATION??) and etc etc.

3) When we finally got to the restaurant, we asked for hot water. Our waiter gave us a standard hot water pot, but when we poured it, it had clearly never been cleaned after serving coffee (water was coffee colored). Maybe it's a new fad, tea with coffee? I don't know. After complaining, we got a second new pot, in the same condition. Maybe someone in the kitchen is just not bothering to wash anything, idk. After that, our waiter disappeared and was never to be seen again. Unhappy customer? Just avoid them!

4) When checking in, the attendant said he added my parking ticket to the hotel door keycard. Guess what happened when driving out the next day? The gate said "PLEASE WAIT" for about 2 minutes (while cars are waiting behind me), and then just returned to the main screen. Naturally there are no human attendants, as this hotel seems to be cutting costs in all the wrong ways. I had to push a button on the kiosk that gave me an extremely garbled voice in another call center somewhere. I still have no idea what they said back to me, but the gate opened, so I drove out.

On top of all that frustration, it's irritating as a whole how much the whole hotel industry in Vegas has started nickel-and-diming everything. They're as bad as the airline industry! Let's see...
1) Advertise ridiculously low hotel price, tricking nobody.
2) Tack on a $39 resort fee (how is this not just part of the room price? you're not tricking anyone here)
3) Make sure none of the rooms have good cell coverage (ok maybe this wasn't intentional)
4) Charge way too much for parking (free at 2 star hotels)
5) Only allow 2 devices per room to use WIFI. Charge extra for more devices.
6) Don't provide any sort of breakfast credit.
7) Outsource and\/or automate everything, poorly (restaurant questions, restaurant reservations, parking attendants, hotel check-in).

In preparation for a Vegas list I am putting together for future reference, I am back tracking on this review from a few years ago when I saw U2 and spent a few days in Vegas. Never stayed at the hotel, however, love browsing and spending time here 'cause my kid at heart is at play. I haven't done much time in Paris, therefore, cannot comment if this properly emulates the feel of the city, however, for what it is I had fun. The souvenirs are cheesy "Paris souvenirs just like NY NY, however, more in it or the laugh than actual retail therapy. Not a lot of interaction with the staff personally but they looked all happy serving people at the front desk.

One of the cheaper hotels for our group to stay in, so we picked this place. I have always enjoyed European decor, so I fell in love with this place. We had two double queen rooms, which were more than enough room for all of us. The view from our room was beautiful, the room was cleaned, the bathroom was very pretty. We didn't stay very long in our rooms, really only to sleep, so it did the job for us. I really enjoyed walking downstairs, as it mimicked a French road. We dined at the buffet, at the pizza shoppe, and at the cafe. Free alcohol when you gamble (so I went as slow as I could in order to get some free drinks). Pool was beautiful and clean. All of the service women and men were very nice and attentive to all of us.

Stayed at Paris for a company convention. Carpet in room is very soiled\/stained. Found blood stains on curtains. Woodwork in room is very knocked up.  Bed linens are worn & dirty. This hotel is in need of a major update. Check- in took over an hour. Service in restaurants is average

This hotel is koo, i really like the service which they give maybe i dont like it tooo much because i would always stay here as a kid and what the hell is there to do in vegas as a kid, STAY IN ROOMS!? PARIS 3 STAR. Sorry!


TFR

The room was a bit run down. I was definitely disappointed. The front desk people were obviously we're not happy with their jobs. I arrived two hours before check-in and was charged $20 extra for an early check-in fee.
The biggest problem that I had was that I had put a do not disturb sign on my door, but when I returned just a few hours later my room had been cleaned. Now, most people don't think that this would be an issue. I like to organize my belongings and put my items in the safe prior to housekeeping coming into my room. I'm just weird like that.  
I did give them to stars because I was able to get free Wi-Fi and the location was great.
Taking into account my overall experience, I don't think that I would return.

Well as long as you don't mind sleeping in someone else's dirt or using their dirty towels thinking you have a clean one because they are nicely folded, then you will be ok... but seriously 

I was traveling for work and I walk in to my room and I'm like motel 6 is cleaner and has a fresher code of paint then these hotel rooms. The carpet looks like it's from a well used porn site, my in room fridge did not work, the tv had lines in it ... then I took a shower ( I know I don't why I did other then I was tried from traveling and just wanted to go bed).... I didn't notice until I was in the shower that someone left their nose boogers, hair and string in the shower ... as I ran out of the shower not to slip I threw down the bath matt and there was dried blood on it!!!!!

I called downstairs for a manager 30 minutes ago and I am still waiting for the manager .... 

My co workers room has a dead cockroach and trash still in her room... disgusting

Our first visit to Paris Las Vegas as a room guest.  We'd been though the place before when staying at Bally's, but never had a room there, until now.  We were pleasantly surprised with our room (room 2039).  Small but well appointed, clean and easy to get to from the elevators.  I don't care for all the French theme truthfully, but that is the theme of this joint, so I coped as best I could.  We enjoyed the pool here too.  Nothing too fancy though, which is fine with me.  We'd stay here again, but probably won't unless it's comped.  We aren't strip people.....prefer off strip or downtown.  It was a good stay though, and I'd recommend it to anyone.
I loved this hotel. The room was gorgeous with a beautiful view and super comfy bed!  Its in a great locarion... Across from the Bellagio. Definitely stay here its nice and not too pricey.

I was visiting Vegas for a friends wedding and my coworker suggested that we should stay at the Paris. I passed this recommendation along and all of us stayed there. I split a double room with my friend.  I was very happy with my stay at this hotel.  I have stayed at other hotels in Vegas before, one a lot more expensive and one tons cheaper.  

The rooms are nice and if you're lucky to get a good view then you're really lucky.  The bathrooms are decent size.  There were a lot of mirrors in our room, however, the "red room" that my friends stayed at didn't have any mirrors in their "room" only in the bathroom.  

It was twice as much to stay on Sat. as opposed to Sunday night.  

I would prob. stay at Paris again during my next visit.  The pool is really great, your friends (from other hotels) can also come by and hang out and its fun to just chill out and stare at the Eiffel Tower.  

The restaurant service(s) in the main floor can be a little slow.  The services at random places are really hit or miss.   Had a great time at the piano bar but not so much at the little bakery next door.

Nice Hotel. Clean, modern, updated rooms with enclosed showers (separate from the bathtub). Friendly and prompt service from all the staff. Great Value with rooms for less than $100 much of the time. 
Nice restaurants with anything from $10 sandwhiches\/pizzas up to $200\/person fine dining with an amazing view (Eiffel Tower Restaurant). Mon Ami Gabi is one of the best restauarants in Vegas, with a patio right on the strip. The piano bar is cool and there are tons of stores, especially when you venture down the hallway to Bally's. Planet Hollywood Mall is next door. We never found any reason to venture more than a mile away from our hotel during our entire stay!
TIP: Spring for the extra $50\/night for the "Rendevous Lounge." Daily breakfast bar and nightly dinner\/hors d' ouvre bar with two "Build it yourself" cocktails included per day (mine were usually "triples" and no one ever counted how many we had). Good food and drink available here for a great deal.

My friends and I didn't really know what to expect since it was all of our first times in Las Vegas as adults! We booked a room at Paris through Expedia, as per another friend's suggestion. I suggest reserving through Expedia or other websites to save money! The location is ideal since it is right at the center of The Strip. A cab ride to\/from the airport is no more than $20, and a trip to the north or south of The Strip is about $10-$15.

Check-in time is 4pm and check-out is at 11am. They don't charge for late check-ins thankfully. Also, they can hold your luggage for as long as you need them to, after you check-out. We were supposed to get in at around 10pm, but didn't arrive until nearly 12am due to a delayed flight. The line was still long to check-in, as there were only two people working at the counters. We got our two queen beds as requested, but were placed in a smoking room since we had arrived so late and the rooms were already filled. However, the staff did put a note for us to switch to a non-smoking floor the second night if the room reeked too much of smoke. 

The smell was much too overwhelming when we walked in. Thankfully, when checking in, they told us we could request for someone to spray air freshener, and some o-zone machine could be brought up as well.
